editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

notesStmt.note: 'The English moor' (E.1782[1]) and 'The love-sick court'(E.1782[2]) have separate title pages, continuous pagination and register, and a final leaf of epilogue. 'Covent Garden weeded' (E.1782[3]) and 'The nevv academy' (E.1782[4]) have separate title pages, continous register, separate pagination, and a final leaf of advertisements. 'Covent garden weeded' has t.p. which reads: 'The weeding of the Covent-Garden'. 'The queen and concubine' (E.1782[5]) has its own t.p., continous pagination and register, and a final leaf of advertisements.

div.p: A posthume of Richard Brome, an ingenious servant, and imitator of his master, that famously renowned poet Ben Johnson.

quote.p:
Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare poetae.
dramatis personae.

div.p: London, printed for Andrew Crook, and are to be sold at the green dragon in st. Paul's churchyard: and Henry Broom at the gun in ivy-lane. 1658.

div.head: Upon Agla ãra printed in folio.
div.l: By this large margin did the poet mean
To have a comment writ upon his scene?
Or is it that the ladies, who never look
On any but a poem or playbook,
May, in each page, have space to scribble down
When such a lord, or fashion comes to town.
As swains in almanacs account do keep,
When their cow calved, and when they bought their sheep?
Ink is the life of paper: 'tis meet then,
That this which scaped the press should feel the pen.
A room with one side furnished, or a face
Painted halfway, is but a fair disgrace.
This great voluminous pamphlet may be said
To be like one that hath more hair than head;
More excrement than body. Trees, which sprout
With broadest leaves, have still the smallest fruit.
When I saw so much white, I did begin
To think Aglaura either did lie in,
Or else took penance. Never did I see
(Unless in bills dashed in the chancery).
So little in so much; as if the feet
Of poetry, like law, were sold by th'sheet.
If this new fashion should but last one year,
Poets, as clerks, would make our paper dear.
Doth not the artist err, and blast his fame
that sets out pictures lesser than the frame?
Was ever chamberlain so mad, to dare
To lodge a child in the great bed at Ware?
Aglaura would please better, did she lie
I'th' narrow bounds of an epitome.
Pieces that are weaved of the finest twist,
(As silk and plush) have still more stuff than list.
She, that in Persian habit made great brags,
Degenerates in this excess of rags;
Who, by her giant-bulk this only gains,
Perchance in libraries to hang in chains.
'Tis not in book, as cloth; we never say
Make london-measure, when we buy a play:
But rather have them paired: those leaves be fair
To the judicious, which more spotted are.
Give me the sociable pocketbooks.
These empty Folio's only please the cooks.

div.head: A song.
div.l: A way with all grief and give us more sack.
'Tis that which we love, let love have no lack.
Nor sorrow, nor care can cross our delights,
Nor witches, nor goblins, nor buttery sprights,
Though the candles burn dim while we can do thus,
We'll scorn to fly them: but we'll make them fly us.
Old sack, and old songs, and a merry old crew
Will fright away sprights, when the ground looks blue.

div.head: A prologue.
div.l: He that could never boast, nor seek the way,
To prepare friends to magnify his play,
Nor rail at's auditory for unjust,
If they not liked it nor was so mistrust.
Full ever in himself, that he besought
Preapprobation though they liked it not.
Nor ever had the luck to have his name
Clapped up above this merit. Nor the shame
To be cried down below it. He this night
Your fair and free attention does invite.
Only he prays no prejudice be brought
By any that beforehand wish it naught.
And that ye all be pleased to hear and see,
With candour suiting his integrity.
That for the writer. Something we must say,
Now in defence of us, and of the play
We shall present no scandal or abuse,
To virtue or to honour. Nor traduce
Person of worth. Nor point at the disgrace
Of any one residing in the place,
On which our scene is laid, nor any action show,
Of thing has there been done, for ought we know.
Though it be probable that such have been.
But if some vicious persons be brought in.
As no new buildings, nor the strongest hold
Can keep out rats and vermin bad and bold.
Let not the sight of such be ill endured;
All sores are seen and searched before th' are cured.
As ruffian, bawd, and the licentious crew,
Too apt to pester situations new.

div.head: Another prologue.
div.l: 'Tis not amiss ere we begin our play,
To entreat you, that you take the same survey
Into your fancy, as our poet took,
Of Covent-garden, when he wrote his book.
Some ten years since, when it was grown with weeds.
Not set, as now it is, with noble seeds.
Which make the garden glorious. And much
Our poet craves and hopes you will not grutch
It him, that since so happily his pen
Foretold its fair improvement, and that men
Of worth and honour should renown the place.
The play may still retain its former grace.

div.head: To my lord of Newcastle, on his play called the variety. He having commanded to give him my true opinion of it.
div.l: I could not think these seven years, but that I
In part a poet was, and so might lie,
By the poetic licence. But I find
Now I am none, and strictly am confined
To truth, if therefore I subpoena'd were
Before the court of chancery to swear.
Or if from thence I should be higher sent,
And on my life unto a parliament
Of wit and judgement, there to certify
What I could say of your variety:
I would depose each scene appeared to me
An act of wit, each act a comedy,
And all was such, to all that understood,
As knowing Johnson, swore by God 'twas good.

list.item: Rooksbill, a great builder in Covent-garden.
Crosswill, a country gentleman, lodger in his buildings.
Cockbrain, a justice of peace, the weeder of the garden.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I marry sir! This is something like! These appear like buildings! Here's architecture expressed indeed! It is a most sightly situation, and fit for gentry and nobility.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: When it is all finished, doubtless it will be handsome.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
It will be glorious: and yond magnificent piece, the Piazzo, will excel that at Venice, by hearsay, (I never travelled). A hearty blessing on their brains, honours, and wealths, that are projectors, furtherers, and performers of such great works. And now I come to you Mr. Rooksbill: I like your row of houses most incomparably. Your money never
shone so on your counting-boards, as in those structures.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I have piled up a leash of thousand pounds in walls and windows there.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It will all come again with large increase.

And better is your money thus let out on red and white, then upon black and white, I say. You cannot think how I am taken with that row! How even and straight they are! And so are all indeed. The surveyor ( whate'er he was) has manifested himself the master of his great art. How he has wedded strength to beauty; state to uniformity; commodiousness with perspicuity! All, all as't should be!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: If all were as well tenanted and inhabited by worthy persons.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Phew; that will follow. What new plantation was ever peopled with the better sort at first; nay, commonly, the lewdest blades, and naughtypacks are either necessitated to 'em, or else do prove the most forward venturers. Is not lime and hair the first in all your foundations? do we not soil or dung our lands, before we sow or plant any thing that's good in 'em? And do not weeds creep up first in all gardens? and why not then in this? which never was a garden until now; and which will be the garden of gardens, I foresee't. And for the weeds in it, let me alone for the weeding of them out. And so as my reverend ancestor justice Adam overdo, was wont to say, in heaven's name and the Kings, and for the good of the commonwealth I will go about it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p:
I would a few more of the worshipful hereabouts, (Whether they be in commission or not) were as well minded that way as you are sir; we should
then have all sweet and clean, and that quickly too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have thought upon a way for't, Mr. Rooksbill: and I will pursue it, viz. to find out all the enormities, yet be myself unspied: whereby I will tread out the spark of impiety, whilst it is yet a spark and not a flame; and break the egg of a mischief, whilst it is yet an egg and not a cockatrice. Then doubt not of worthy tenants for your houses Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope, sir, your best furtherance.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I had a letter burr last night from a worthy friend, a west-country gentleman, that is, now coming up with his family to live in town here; and desire is to inhabit in these buildings. He was to lie at Hammersmith last night, and requested an early meeting of me this morning here, to assist him in the taking of a house. It is my business hither; for he could never do't himself. He has the oldest touchy, wrangling humour. ‚Äî but in a harmless way; for he hurts nobody , and pleases himself in it. His children have all the trouble of it, that do anger him in obeying him sometimes. You will know him anon. I mean, he shall be your tenant. And luckily he comes.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is not enough you tell me of obedience. Or that you are obedient. But I will be obeyed in my own way. Do you see ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My noble friend Mr. Croswill, right happily met.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your troublesome friend Mr. cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
No trouble at all, sir, though I have prevented
yours in finding a fit house for you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You ha' not ha' you, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Actum est Mr. Croswill. But civility pardon me, is not this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All the she-things I have: and would I were well rid of her too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Katherine, welcome ‚Äî Mr. Gabriel, I take it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel Croswill is my name.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But where's your younger son Mihill? There's a spark!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: A spark! A dunce I fear by this time like his brother sheepshead there.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel is my proper name.

sp.speaker: Gros.
sp.p: I have not seen him this twelvemonth, since I chambered him a student here in town.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: In town, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He knows not yet of my coming neither, nor shall not, till I steal upon him; and if I find him mopish like his brother, I know what I will do.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Have you not heard from him lately?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, often by his letters, less I could read more comfort in 'em. I fear he's turned precisian, for all his epistles end with amen; and the-matter of 'em is such as if he could teach me to ask him blessing.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: A comfortable hearing of a young man.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Is it so sir? but I'll new mould him if it be so. ‚Äî I'll tell you Mr. cockbrayne; never was such a father so crossed in his children. They will not obey me in my way. I grant, they do things that other fathers would rejoice at. But I will be obeyed in my own way, d'ye see. Here's my eldest son. Mark how he stands, as if he had learned a posture at Knightsbridge
spittle as we came along whilere. He was not only born without wit, but with an obstinate resolution, never to have any. I mean, such wit as might become a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Was that resolution born in him think you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It could never grow up in him still as it does else. When I would have him take his horse, and follow the dogs, and associate gentlemen, in hawking, hunting, or such like exercises, he'll run you a foot five mile another way, to meet the brothers of the separation, at such exercises as I never sent him to (I am sure) on worky days. And whereas most gentlemen run into other men's books, in hands that they care not who reads, he has a book of his own short-writing in his pocket, of such stuff as is fit for no man's reading indeed but his own.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely sir. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sure you are an ass. Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You are my father.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What comfort should I have, were my son such.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: And he has nothing but hanged the head, as you see now, ever since holiday sports were cried up in the country. And but for that, and to talk with some of the silenced pastors here in town about it, I should not have drawn him up.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I would I could change a son w' you sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What kind of thing is thy son? ha! dost thou look like one that could have a son fit for me to father, ha? And yet the best take both, and to please you at all adventures, ha?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I am sure there cannot be a worse, or more debauched reprobate than mine is living.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
And is the devil too good a master for
him, think'st thou, ha? Wherein can I deserve so ill at thy hands, fellow, whatever thou art, that thou shouldst wish me cumbered with a worse burden, when thou hearest me complain of this, ha? What is this fellow that you dare know him, friend Cockbrayn? I will not dwell within three parishes of him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My tenant! Bless me from him. I had rather all my rends were bawdy houses.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Think nothing of his words, he'll forget all instantly. The best natured man living.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Dost thou stand like a son now that hears his father abused, ha?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am praying for the conversion of the young man he speaks of.

sp.speaker: Coek.
sp.p: Well said, Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But by the way, where's your son Anthony? have you not heard of him yet?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Never since he forsook me, on the discontent he took, in that he might not marry your daughter there. And where he lives, or whether he lives or not, I know not. I hope your daughter is a comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, in keeping her chamber whole weeks together, sullening upon her samplery breech-work, when I was in hope she would have made me a grandfather ere now. But she has a humour, forsooth, since we put your son by her, to make me a match-broker, her marriage-maker; when I tell you friend, there has been so many untoward matches of parents making, that I have sworn she shall make her own choice, though it be of one I hate. Make me her matchmaker! Must I obey her, or she me, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I wish, with tears, my son had had her now.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Wherein sir, (Under correction do I disobey you?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: In that very word, under correction, thou disobeyest me. Are you to be under correction at these years? ha! If I ha' not already taught you manners beyond the help of correction, go, seek a wiser father to mend 'em.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave, dear sir, in my excuse. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Leave out correction then.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: If I were forward as many maidens are,
To wish a husband, must I not be sought?
I never was a Gadder: and my mother,
Before she died, adjured me to be none.
I hope you'll give me leave to keep your house.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: La there again! How subtly she seeks dominion over me! No, housewife, no; you keep no house of mine. I'll nestle you no longer under my wing. Are you not fledge; I'll have you fly out I, as other men's daughters do; and keep a house of your own if you can find it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: We had a kinswoman flew out too lately, I take it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What tellest thou me of her; wiseacres? Can they not fly out a little, but they must turn arrant whores, ha? Tell me of your kinswoman? 'tis true, she was my niece; she went to't a little afore her time? some two years since, and so fled from religion; and is turned Turk, we fear. And what of that in your precisiancial wisdom? I have such children as no man has. But (As I was saying,) would ye top me housewife, ha! Look you, now I chide her, she says nothing. Is this obedience, ha?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Perhaps, I might unfortunately cast my affection on a man that would refuse me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: That man I would desire to know; show me that man; see if I swinge him not dares slight my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Still the old humour, self-willed, cross, and touchy; but suddenly reconciled. Come, Mr. Croswil, to the business.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: O, you told me of a house you had found for me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes sir. And here's the landlord.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Does he look, or go like one could let a house worthy of me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sir, we have able builders here, that will not carry lest show of their buildings on their backs. This is a rich sufficient man, I assure you, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I cry him heartily mercy, and embrace him. And now I note you better, you look like thrift itself.
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas above upon a bellconie. Gabriel gazes at her. Dorcas is habited like a courtesan of Venice.
sp.p: I cannot think you will throw away your houses at a cast. You have a son, perhaps, that may, by the commendations you gave of him. Let's see your house.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Come away Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come sir, what do you gape and shake the head at there? I'll lay my life he has spied the little cross upon the new church yond, and is at defiance with it. Sirrah, I will make you honour the first syllable of my name. My name is will. Croswill, and I will have my humour. Let those that talk of me for it, speak their pleasure, I will do mine.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I shall obey you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now you are in the right. You shall indeed. I'll make your heart ache else, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
But truly I was looking at that image; that
painted idolatrous image yonder, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O heresy! It is some lady, or gentlewoman standing upon her balcony.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Her balcony? Where is it? I can spy from her foot to her face, yet I can see no balcony she has.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What a knave's this: that's the balcony she stands on, that which jets out so on the forepart of the house; every house here has one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: 'Tis very good; I like the jetting out of the forepart very well; it is a gallant fashion indeed.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I guess what she is, whate'er I have said. O justice look to thine office.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come now to this house, and then to my son Mihil, the spark you spoke of. And if I find him cross too, I'll cross him: let him look to't ‚ñ™ d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'll see you housed; and then about my project, which is for weeding of this hopeful garden. Ex. omnes.
sp.stage: Gabriel stays last looking up at her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Why should not we in England use that freedom
The famous courtesans have in Italy:
We have the art, and know the theory
To allure and catch the wand'ring eyes of lovers;
Yea, and their hearts too: but our stricter laws
Forbids the public practice, our desires
Are high as theirs; our wills as apt and forward;
Our wits as ripe, our beauties more attractive;
Or travellers are shrewd liars. Where's the let?
Only in bashful coward custom, that
Stoops i'the shoulders, and submits the neck
To bondage of authority; to these laws,
That men of feeble age and weaker eyesight
Have framed to bar their sons from youthful pleasures.
Possets and caudles on their queasy stomachs,
whilst I fly out in brave rebellion;
And offer, at the least, to break these shackles
That holds our legs together: and begin
A fashion, which pursued by Cyprian dames,
May persuade justice to allow our games.
Who knows? I'll try. Francisca bring my lute.
sp.stage: While she is tuning her lute: enter Nich. Rookesbill, Anthony in a false beard, Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Troth I have a great mind to be one of the Philoblathici, a brother of the blade and battoon, as you translate it; now ye have beat it into my head: but I fear I shall never come on and off handsomely. I have metal enough methinks, but I know not how methinks to put it out.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: We'll help you out with it, and set it flying for you never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Obotts, you mean my money metal, I mean my valour metal I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace, hark.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Tother flies fast enough already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pox on ye peace.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O most melodious.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Most odious, did you say? It is methinks most odoriferous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What new device can this be? Look!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She is vanished. Is't not the mountebanks wife that was here; and now come again to play some new merry tricks by herself.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A botts on't, I never saw that mountebank; they say, he brought the first resort into this new plantation, and sowed so much seed of knavery and cozenage here, that 'tis feared 'twill never out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay but this creature: what can she be?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And then again, he drew such flocks of idle people to him, that the players, they say, cursed him abominably.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.p: Thou ever talkest of the wrong matter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Cry mercy brothers of the blade and battoun: do you think if I give my endeavour to it, I shall ever learn to roar and carry it as you do, that have it naturally, as you say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, as we'll beat it into you. But this woman, this musical woman, that set herself out to show so, I would be satisfied in her.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And she be as able as she seems, she has in her to satisfy you, and you were a brother of ten blades, and ten baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow ‚Äî peace. I'll baton thy teeth into thy tongue else; she bears a stately presence. Thou never sawest her before: didst thou Toney?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No; but I heard an inkling at the Paris tavern last night of a she-gallant-that had travelled France and Italy; and that she would ‚Äî

sp.speaker: (Clot.
sp.p: Baton thy teeth into thy tongue.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Plant some of her foreign collections, the fruits of her travels, in this garden here, to try how they would grow or thrive on English earth.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Young big was speaking of such a one to me, and that she was a Mumper.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: What's that a sister of the scabbard, brother of the blade?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come, come; we'll in, we'll in; 'tis one of our father's buildings; I'll see the inhabitants. Some money clot. furnish I say, and quickly. ‚Äî I vow ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You shall, you shall.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What shall I?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Vow twice before you have it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow, and I vow again, I'll coin thy brains. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take your powl money; I thought I would have my will; and the word I look-for, I'll coin thy brains. ‚Äî

I do not love to give my money for nothing, I have a volume of words here, the worst of 'em is as good as a blow; and than I save my crown whole half a dozen times a day, by half a crown a time, there's half in half saved by that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come let's appear civil, till we have our entrance, and then as occasion serves ‚Äî
Who would you speak withal?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your mistress, little one.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you know her sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but I would know her, that's the business: I mean the musical gentlewoman that was fiddling, and so many in the what-do-call-it e'en now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What-doe-call her sir, I pray?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What-doe-call her; 'tis not come to that yet, prithee let me see and speak with her first.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are disposed I think.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What should we do here else?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You won't thrust in upon a body whether one will or no.

sp.speaker: Ant. Nic.
sp.p: Away you monkey.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O me, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O my brave Philoblathici. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What's the matter the girl cries out so?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I know not: I fear some rude company, some of the wild crew are broke into the house.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Within. Whether would you go, you won't rob the house will ye?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Will ye be quiet whiskin?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O me 'tis so: hell's broke loose; this comes of your new fingle-fangle fashion, your preposterous Italian way forsooth: would I could have kept my old way of pots and pipes, and my strong-water course for customers: the very first twang of your fiddle guts has broke all, and conjured a legion of devils among us.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Nay, there's but a leash of us. How now?
Who have we here? Are these the far travelled ladies?
O thou party perpale, or rather parboiled bawd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What shall I do? Dam. Out alas; sure they are devils indeed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Art thou travelled cross the seas from the Bankside hither, old countess of codpiece-row?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Party perpale and parboiled bawd. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And is this the damsel that has been in France and Italy? Clot. Codpiece-row.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Peace ye roaring scabs: I'll be sworn she supped at Paris tavern last night, and lay not long ago at the Venice by Whitefriars dock.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Prithee what is she Madge?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A civil gentlewoman you see she is.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She has none of the best faces: but is she warrantable; I have not had a civil night these three months.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Nor none are like to have here, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Madge how I do long thy thing to ding diddle ding.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O Nick, I am not in the humour, no more is she to be o'the merry pin now; I am sure her case is too lamentable. But if you will all sit down, I'll give you a bottle of wine, and we'll relate her story to you, so you will be civil. Nic well for once, I care not if we be.
sp.stage: A table bottle, light, and tobacco stales.
sp.p: Let us set to't then; sit down brother Toney, sit down gentlewoman, we shall know your name anon, I hope it will fall in your story; sit down clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You will call me brother clotpoll too when I have taken my oath, and paid my entrance into the faternity of the blade and the baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis like we shall. Now lady of the Stygian lake, thou black infernal Madge, begin the dismal story, whilst I begin the bottle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: This gentlewoman whose name is Damyris.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Damyris stay. Her nickname then is dammy, so we may call her when we grow familiar: and to begin that familiarity, Dammy here's to you. ‚Äî drink.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And what's your nickname I pray sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nick: only Nick, Madge there knows it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then I believe your name is Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow-witty. Yes Dammy, and my surname is Rooksbill, and so is my fathers too: and what do you make o'that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Nothing not I sir: sure this is he.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And I would he were nothing, so I had all he has: I must have tother glass to wash him out of my mouth, he furs it worse than Mondonga's tobacco. Here old Madge, and to all the birds that shall wonder at thy howletship, when thou ridest in an ivy-bush, called a cart.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well mad Nick, I'll pledge thee in hope to see as many flutter about the tree, that thou shalt climb backwards.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A pox thou wilt be stifled with offal and carrot leaves before that day.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, what talk's this? 'tis he I am confident.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: These are our ordinary compliments, we wish no harm.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No Dammy I vow, not I to any breathing.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But your father Nick. ‚Äî is he that Rooksbill. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But my fathet; pox rot ye, why do ye put me in mind of him again, he sticks i'my throat, now I'll wash him a little further. ‚Äî here brother Toney

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gramercy brother Nick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the brothers that are, and are to be of the blade and the baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There said you well clotpoll: here 'tis ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I would but have asked you whether your father were that Rooksbill that is called the great builder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Yes marry is it he forsooth; he has built I know not how many houses hereabout, though he goes dammy as if he were not worth a groat; and all his clothes I vow are not worth this hilt, except those he wears, and prays for fair weather in, on my lord mayor's day; and you are his tenant, though perhaps you know it not, and may be mine; therefore use me well: for this house and the rest I hope will be mine, as well as I can hope he is mortal, of which I must confess I have been in some doubt, though now I hope again, he will be the first shall lay his bones i'the new church, though the churchyard be too good
for him before 'tis consecrated. So give me the to-the cup, for now he offends my stomach. Here's to thee now clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the sisters of the scabbard brother in election. D'ye hear, pray talk of his father no more, for the next brings him to the belly-work, and then he'll drink him quite through him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And so we shall have a foul house.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No he shall stick there. Now to the story gentlewoman, 'twas that we sat for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I to the story, I vow I had almost forgotten it; and I am the worst at sack in a morning: dear Dammy to the story.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Good sir my heart's too full to utter't.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Troth and my head's too full to hear it: but I'll go out and quarrel with somebody to settle my brains, then go down to Mich Crosswill to put him in mind of our meeting today; then if you will meet me at the goat at dinner, we'll have it all at large.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you be there indeed sir, I would speak with you seriously.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Dammy if I be not, may my father out live me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We both here promise you he shall be there by noon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Lady, 'tis sworn by blade and by baton.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This will be the bravest discovery for Mihill, the new Italian bona roba Catsoe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why so sad on the sudden niece.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But do you think he'll come as he has promised.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: He never breaks a promise with any of us 'Though he fail all the honest part o'the world: but I trust you are not taken with the ruffian, you'll ne'er get penny by him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I prithee peace, I care not.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But mistress, there is a gallant now below, a jingle boy indeed, that has his pockets full of, crowns that chide for vent. Shall I call him up to you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will see no man.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: How's that? I hope you jest.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Indeed, I hope you jest.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You will not hinder the house, I hope. Marry heigh. This were a humour and 'twould last. Go fetch him up.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll fly then out at window. Nay, by this steel 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's the matter? have I got a mad woman into the house. What do you go about to break me the first day of your coming, before you have hanselled a couch or a bedside in't. Were you but now all o'th heigh to set yourself out for a sign with your fiddle come twang, and promise such wonders, forsooth, and will not now be seen. Pray what's the riddle.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll tell thee all anon. Prithee excuse me. I know thy share of his sin's bounty would not come to thus much, take it, I give it thee. And prithee let me be honest till I have a mince to be otherwise, and I'll hinder thee nothing.

sp.speaker: M‚óèd.
sp.p: Well, I'll dismiss the gallant, and send you, sirrah, for another wench. I'll have Bess Bufflehead again. This kicksy-wincy wincy Giddibrain will spoil all I'll no more Italian tricks. ‚Äî
sp.l: Thus some have by the frenzy of despair
Fumously run into the sea to throw
Their wretched bodies, but when come near
They saw the billows rise, heard Boreas' blow,
and horrid death appearing on the main,
A sudden fear hath sent them back again.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nay, but honest shoemaker; thy honest price.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I tell you intruth, sir, 'tis as good a boot as ever you pulled on in your life.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A little too straight, I doubt. What do you think of my boots honest tailor.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: They do exceeding handsomely, never trust me sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Never fear it tailor, you shall trust me, and please you.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: You are pleasant sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And what do you think of my suit shoemaker? can you say as much for the tailor as he for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A very neat suit, sir, and becomes you excellent.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Honest men both, and hold together; one would little think you were so near neighbours. Well, you, have fitted me both, I must confess. But how I shall fit you, now there's the point.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: There's but one way for than and please you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: With paying us our money sit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Still both in a tale, I can not but commend your neighbourhood, I muse my laundress stays,
I sent her three or four ways for moneys. But do not you stay for that. I have ways enough to pay you. I have ploughs a going that you dream not of.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: No indeed, sir, we dream of nothing but ready money, sleeping or waking.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I shall be rich enough never fear't. I have a venture in the new soap business man.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: We are but servants, sir. And our masters themselves have no faith, in slippery projects.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Besides, the women begin to grumble against that slippery project shrewdly, and, 'tis feared, will mutiny shortly .

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Byrlakin, and they may prove more troublesome than a commotion of sailors.
O welcome, laundress, where's the money.

sp.speaker: Laundress
sp.p: Not a penny of money, sir, can I get. But here's one come to town has brought you enough, and you can have grace to finger it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Who's that I prithee.

sp.speaker: Laundress
sp.p: Your father, your father sir. I met his man by great chance, who told me his master means to steal upon you presently, and take you as he finds you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Is he come up with his cross tricks. I heard he was to come. And that he means to live here altogether. He has had an aim these dozen years to live in town here, but never was fully bent on't until the proclamation of restraint spurred him up. 'tis such a crossewill. Well, he is my father, and I am utterly undone if thou helpest me not now at a pinch, at a pinch, dear laundress. Go borrow me a gown,
and some four or five law-books? for, I protest, mine are in Duck-lane. Nay, trudge, sweet laundress, trudge. ‚ÄîEx. Laun.honest tailor and shoemaker convey yourselves away quietly, and I'll pay you tomorrow, as I am a gentleman:

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: As I am a shoemaker, and that's a kind of a gentleman, you know, I'll not stir till I have my money, I am not an ass sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: nobody says thou art.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: I have had too many such tricks put upon me i' my days.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A trick! as I hope for money it is no trick.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Well sir, trick or no trick. I must have my money or my boots, and that's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A pox o'th' boots, so my legs were out of 'em. Would they were i'thy throat, spurs and all, you will not out.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: No marry will we not.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Well-said shoemaker, I commend thee, thou hast a better heart than I, though my stomach's good.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: O well said, my good laundress. How am I bound to thee; yet all this won't do't laundress. Thou must bestir thy stumps a little further, and borrow me a couple of gowns more for these rascals here that will not away.

sp.speaker: Laundress
sp.p: How! won't away? And they were well served, they would be thrust out of doors for saucy companions. Your masters would not put a gentleman to his trumps thus.

sp.speaker: M;.
sp.p:
Nay, sweet laundress, restrain thy tongue, and stretch thy feet. A couple of gowns, good
laundress, and forget not caps. Ex.if I do now furnish you like civil lawyers, and you do not keep your countenances; if ever you do but peep in at the hall-door at Christmas to see the revels, I'll have you set i'th' stocks for this believe it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If you do, sir, I may hap be even with you before the year comes about, and set you in our stocks for't.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: But will you make lawyers of us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you a mind to have your money you unbelieving rascals.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I see your drift, and hope you'll prove an honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou hast some hope, though no faith nor trust in any man.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Alas, sir, our masters sit at great rends, and keep great families.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, they are removed into the new plantation here, where, they say, are a tribe of infidel-tradesmen, that have made a law within yourselves to put no trust in gentlemen. But bear yourselves handsomely here you were best. I am acquainted with a crew that haunts about your habitations, with whom I will join, and so batter your windows one of these nights else. ‚Äî oh welcome, laundress, how dost thou toil for me.

sp.speaker: Laundress
sp.p: Your father's talking, as I am a woman, below. ‚Äî as thou art a woman below, well-said. Come on with these gowns, and let's see how you'll look. If we had time, the shoemaker should wash his face; but seeing there is no remedy; pull the cap in your eyes, and good enough. Now laundress, set us stools, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Laundress
sp.p: I hear him coming up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Now let him come, we are ready for him. Shoemaker, keep your hand underneath the
book, that the pitch do not discover you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And Taylor, be sure you have no needle on your sleeve, nor thread about your neck.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I warrant you too for me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: He's entered.
sp.stage: Enter Croswill, Belt, and stand aside.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Remitter, I say, is where a man hath two titles, that is to say, one of an elder, the other of a later. And he cometh to the land by the later title; yet the law adjudgeth him to be in by the force of the elder title. If the tenant in the tail discontinue the tail, and after he diseaseth his discontinue, and so dieth seized, whereby the tenants descend to their issue, as to his cousin inheritable by force of the tail. In this case the tenants descend, who have right by force of the tail, a remitter in the tail taken for that in the law, shall put and adjudge him to be in by force of descent. Pox on ye, speak something good or bad, somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The remitter, you say, is seized i'th' tail.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Excellent shoemaker, I say so, and again, I say, that if the tenant in the tail in feoff his son, or his cousin, inheritable by force of the tail, the which son or cousin at the time of the feoffment is within age, and after the tenant in the tail dierh, this is a remitter to the heir in the tail to whom the feoffment is made, now tailor.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Think you so, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Look either Fitzherbert, Perkins, or Dier, and you shall find it in the second part of Richard Cordelyon. So much for remitter. Now I'll put a plain homespun case, as a man may say, which we call a moot-case.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I pray do sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Some father might take joy of such a son now. This takes not me. No, this is not my way.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: The case is this
Pull up your grounds closer and be hanged, you are a tailor, and you: a shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you owe us money.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I put the case, I do, to you for a suit of clothes.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And to you for a pair of boots.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have broke my day with you both. Suppose so.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Very well, we do.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You clap a sergeant of my back. I put in bail, remove it, and carry it up into the upper court, with habeas-corpus; bring it down again into the lower court with procedendo; then take it from thence, and bring it into the chancery with a certiorari; I; and if you look not to it, bring it out of the chancery again, and thus will I keep you from your money till your suit and your boots be worn out before you recover penny of me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: 'Slid but you shall not, your father shall know all first.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Sfoot shoemaker wilt thou be an ass. I do but put a case, have you not seen it tried.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
Away with books. Away with law. Away with madness. Ay, God bless thee, and make thee his servant, and defend thee from law, I say. Take up these books, sirrah, and carry them presently into Paul's churchyard d'ye see, and change them all for histories, as pleasant as profitable; Arthur of Britain,
Primalion of Greece, Amadis of Gaul, and such like de see.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope he does but jest.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And do you hear, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Get bells work, and you can, into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Which bell, sir? Adam Bell, with Clim o'th' 'Clough, and William of Cloudesley.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Adam Bell you ass? Valiant bell that killed the dragon.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You mean st. George.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir jolt-head, do I not. I'll teach you to chop logic, with me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, how shall I answer my borrowed books? Stay belt. Pray sir, do not change my books.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir, sir, I will change them and you too: did I leave thee here to learn fashions and manners, that thou mightst carry thyself like a gentleman, and dost thou waste thy brains in learning a language that I understand not a word of? ha! I had been as good have brought thee up among the wild Irish.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Why alas sir, had I not better keep myself within my chamber, at my study, then be rioting abroad, wasting both money and time, which is more precious than money? if you did know the inconvenience of company, you would rather encourage and commend my retired life, than any ways dehort me from it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why sir did not I keep company think you when I was young? Ha!

sp.speaker: Ml.
sp.p: Yes sir; but the times are much altered, and youth more corrupted now, they did not drink and wench in those days, but nay, oh 'tis abominable in these.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Why this is that I feared, the boys turning
meacock too, after his elder brother, 'twas time to look to him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why Croswill Mich what, not up yet and be hanged. Or ha' ye a wench a-bed weigh. Is this keeping your home. Mihil runs to the door and holds it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Sfoot the rogue Rooksbil and his crew, I feared as much.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Break open the door, let me come to't.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Forbear, or be hanged, you will undo me, my father's here. I'll meet you anon as I am honest.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your father's a clutterdepouch. Nay, I will come then, what mademoiselle do you call father.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You would not believe me. Pray be civil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis so, we will cry mercy, you are busy, we will not moot today then?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope you may excuse me, I'll be w'ye anon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come to the goat Capricorn. We have the bravest new discovery.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: How now! what are these?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: They are gentlemen of my standing, sir, that have a little overstudied themselves, and are somewhat ‚Äî.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Mad; are they not? And so will you be shortly, if you follow these courses. Mooting do they call it? you shall moot nor mute here no longer. Therefore on with your cloak and sword, follow me to the tavern and leave me such long-tailed company as these are, for I do not like them.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No more do I, sir, if I knew how to be rid of 'em.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I think thou hast never a sword, hast thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Where is it, sir, let me see't sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Tis here, under my bed, sir. ‚Äî reach it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why there's a lawyer's trick right, make his weapon companion with his pisspot. Fie, fie, here's a tool indeed. There's money, sir, buy you a good one, one with the mathematical hilt as they term it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It would do better in mathematical books ‚ñ™ sir, offer me no money, pray sir, but for books.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Go to, you are a peevish Jack, do not provoke me: do not you owe me obedience? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes sir, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: 'Tis good you do. Well, take that money; and put yourself into clothes befitting your rank, do so. And let me see you, squirting about without a weapon, like an attorneys clerk in termtime, and I'll weapon you, what, shall I have a noddy of you. This frets him to the liver. Go to, never hang the head for the matter. For I tell thee I will have it so, and herein be known what I am.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are known sufficiently for your cross humour already; in which I'll try you if I can make you double this money, for this will not serve my turn.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What have you told it after me, you had best weigh it too.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No sir, but I have computed that for my present use, here is too much by half, pray sir, take half back.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Body of me, what a perverse knave is this, to cross me thus! Is there too much, say you? ha.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Let me see't. Go thy ways, take thy musty books, and rhy rusty whittle here again. And take your foolish plodding dunci-coxcomely course, till I look after you again. Come away sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, who's the gull now? Taylor, shoemaker, you may go pawn your gowns for any money I am like to have.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: We have all played the lawyers to pretty purpose, in pleading all this while for nothing. Well sir, to avoid further trouble, I am content to withdraw my action, that is, pull off your boots again, and be jogging.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: And for my part, sir, I can do no less than take you by default and nonsuit you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Very good lawyers both, is my father quite gone belt?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Gone in a tempest of high displeasure, sir: and has sent you here all the money he had about him; and bids you refuse it if you dare, 'tis above twice the sum he offered you before; but good sir, do not refuse it. He swears he will try whether you or he shall have his will. Take heed you cross him not too much.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well at thy request, because thou shalt not have anger for carrying it back again, I will accept.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank you sir. Consider, he's your father, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
I do most reverend belt. and would be loath to cross him, although I may as much in taking his money as refusing it, for ought I know, for thou knowest 'tis his custom to cross me, and the rest
of his children in all we do, to try and urge his obedience; 'tis an odd way: therefore to help myself I seem to covet the things that I hate, and he pulls them from me; and makes show of loathing the things I covet, and he hurls them doubly at me, as now in this money.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Are you so crafty?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes, but do thou put it in his head, and I'll pick out thy brains.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You never knew an old servingman treacherous to his young master: what? to the hopes o'th' house; you will be heir, that's questionless: for to your comfort, your elder brother grows every day more fool than the other. But now the rest of the message is, that you make haste, and come to my master to the goat in Covent-garden, where he dines with his new landlord today.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He has taken a house then.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O, a most delicate one, with a curious balcony and all belonging to't most stately.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: At the goat does he dine, sayest thou.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My crew are gone thither too. Pray Mars we fall not foul of one another. Well, go thy way, present my duty to him, I'll follow presently. Tell him I took his money with much unwillingness.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: As lawyers do their fees. Let me alone sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well tailor and shoemaker; you have put me to't, but here's your money.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: 'Twas for that we did put you to't sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Let's see your bill tailor

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Here 'tis, sir, as ready as a watchman's.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Then good words will pass it, 7 li. 4. sh. tell your money; yours is 14 sh. boots and galoshes.
There 'tis and 12. d. to drink.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Are you right tailor.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Yes and please you sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There's a shilling for you too, to spend in bread.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: He knows both our diets. We'll make bold to take leave of your worship.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Not so bold as I'm glad I'm too well rid of you, most courteous gentlemen.

To see what money can do; that can change men's manners, alter their conditions: how tempestuous the slaves were without it. O thou powerful metal! what authority is in thee! Thou art the key to all men's mouths. With thee a man may lock up the jaws of an informer, and without thee he cannot the lips of a lawyer.

div.head: Scoen. ii.
div.stage: Enter crossewill, Rookesbill, Gabriel, Katherine, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Down boy, and bid the cook hasten dinner.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: What will you please to drink in the mean time, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will not drink in the mean time, sir, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: A fine old humorous gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Hold up your head, sirrah, and leave your precise folly. I'll leave you to the wild world else, d'ye see. Is the name of a tavern so odious to you? Ha. Your brother has vexed me sufficiently already, and perhaps he'll refuse to come too! If he dares let him. Welcome Mr. Rooksbil, welcome landlord, and your fair daughter, welcome pretty one. Trust
me a pretty one indeed, pray be acquainted with my daughter there. In your maiden-company, I hope she will not think the tavern such a bug's nest as she did. I had much ado to draw my rebellious children to the tavern after me.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And truly, sir, 'tis the first to my knowledge that ere my daughter came into.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All in good time, she may increase in virtue. But if it be a fault, (As i' my conscience in his thought it is a great transgression) my unsettledness, and unprovidedness else, where or how to entertain a friend, or feed myself, may well excuse us all, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O sir, I cannot enough admire that virtue in your son.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is a vice, as much a vice or more, as is your sons, your castaways as you call him, that sucks no other air, than that of taverns, tap-houses, brothels, and such like. I would their extreme qualities could meet each other at halfway, and so mingle their superfluities of humour unto a mean betwixt 'em. It might render them both allowable subjects, where now the one's a fire-drake in the air, and tother a mandrake in the earth, both mischievous, see how he stands like a mole-catcher. What dirty dogged humour was I in when I got him trow?

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.p: Howe'er his carriage seems distasteful unto you, I could afford (With your allowance, to make conditions of estate agreeable) to give all that is mine to him with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
What a mechanic slave is this, to thank a son of mine, howe'er I underrate him, a fit mate to mingle blood with his more-ditch breed. True, his estate is great, I understand it, but of all foul I love not moorhens. Such another motion
would stir me to roar him down the tavernstairs.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: What do you think on't sirs.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Will you consider of it master Crosswill.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I was never so put to't. I wish we had a stickler. I muse that master cockbrayne stays thus.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: You do not mind my motion sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Uds precious I mind nothing, I am so crossed in mind that I can mind nothing, nor I will mind nothing, d'ye see. Why comes not Mr. Cockbrain, ha!

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Yet you mind him it seems. But he, sir, cannot come, and desires you to hold him excused. He's gone about some special undertaking, for the good of the commonwealth, he says.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Fart for his undertaking; all the world is bent to cross me. What is my young master come? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: My young master Mr. Mihil will be here presently, he said he would follow me at heels, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: And why not come before you, sir. Does he not think that I have waited long enough, sir? sure I'll cross somebody under that knaves pate of yours, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Thus when anybody angers him, I am sure to hear on't.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: So now my spleen is a little palliated, let me speak with you Mr. Rooksbill. Get you down, sirrah; and bring me word, dinner is not ready, and I'll give you as much more, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: That's his way to his stomach.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And is your brother that your father says is so ungracious, so well acquainted with my brother Mihil, say you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O all in all, he's not so familiar with any man, if Mihil Croswill be your brother, as 'tis manifest.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I would not that my father knew it, for all I can expect from him but his blessing, but does your father know it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, I would not he should mistrust it for all he has, blessing and all; and now that I have found you love your brother so well, I will make over my reason and my counsel in trust with you, hoping you will not wrong that trust.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I do, may the due price of treachery be my reward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love your brother, lady, and he loves me. The only good act that ever my brother did, was to bring us acquainted, and is indeed all that he has to live on. For I do succour him with many a stolen piece for the felicity he brought me in your brother's love. Now, my father, whose irreconcilable hate has for ever discarded my brother, should he but dream of their acquaintance, would poison all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But let me ask you, is there an hope betwixt you and my brother ever to come together?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, and a way he has for't, which I understand not yet.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Trust me, I pity you both, your case is very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Love's above all adventures, the more hard the achievement is, the sweeter the reward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I like her spirit well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You sir, come hither, what is hammering in your head now?
Is't not some synodical question to put unto the brothers, concerning whitson-ales and may-games? ha!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely sir, I was premeditating a fit thanksgiving to be rendered before meat in. Taverns, according to the present occasion which the time and place administereth, and that as the spirit shall enable me, shall be delivered before you in due season.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad I know your mind; for that trick, my zealous son, you shall come in at half-dinner, like a chafing-dish of coals, when the sauce is cold, to make use of the heat of your spirit; d' ye see. I love not meat twice dressed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good sir, put the proposition to him, that I made my affection to him, urges it more and more, I never was so taken with a man.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But what's that to your daughter? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: The same affection governs her, she is not mine else.

sp.speaker: Cros
sp.p: Well, hold your peace, and was that your spiritual meditation?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, verily.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come sir, at this gentleman's request I will now put a question to you concerning the flesh. What, think you of yond virgin there his daughter? can you affect her so well as to wish her to be your wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You mean, espoused in holy matrimony.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, I mean so.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Hum hum hum psalm tune. How happy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But do thou say, yes verily to that, and as I hope to have peace in my grave. I'll break the King's peace on thy pate presently.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is a weighty question, and requires due premeditation in a religious answer, pray give me leave to take advice ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What says he, sir?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He says he will talk with a cunning man about her.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Sure you mistake him, sir.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: You are welcome, gentlemen. Will. Harry, Zachary.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Zachary is a good name.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Where are you? he (Rings the bell) show up into the phoenix. Is the checque empty?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Heyday, here's a din.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: A pottle of Canary to the dolphin, score.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: you're welcome, gentlemen, take up the lily-pot.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Half a dozen of clean pipes and a candle for the elephant. They take their own tobacco.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Whose room do they foul sirrah, Harry, Harry?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do elephants take tobacco?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Carry up a jordan for the maidenhead, and a quart of white muskadine for the blue boar.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now methinks , the muskadine for that maidenhead, and the jordan for the boar were better.
Knock above, and a pot thrown. Why boys, drawer, rogues, take up, (Below) by and by, by and by, (Above) wine, tobacco.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What variety of noises is here? and all excellent ill sounds. (Above) call up the fiddlers, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such cries as these went forth before the desolation of the great city.
O profane tinkling the cymbals of Satan; that tickle the care with vanity, to lift up the mind to lewdness. Mine ears shall be that of the adder against the song of the serpent.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O rare, in a young man!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will roar out aloud to drown your incantations. Yea, I will set out a throat even as the beast that belloweth.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Most happy youth!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Hold your peace, sirrah, or I'll make you bellow for something.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot-back, Nick to your own room. Thy father's here too, as I breathe.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My Lucy too, as I live. How the devil got they acquainted? Sure he's his landlord 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Dare you come, sir, you should have stayed now till you had been sent for.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Verily, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you at your verilies too? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But for displeasing you, I had rather have grazed on Littleton's commons, or ha' fasted this fortnight, then come for my repast into this wilderness; but you will ha' it so

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You are in the right sir, I'll have it so indeed, I'll know why I shall not else. What do you know nobody here?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry them mercy, my good brother, ‚Äî and my loving sister.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: But what virtuous men has this man to his sons, and how they thrive in grace against his will, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: What gentlewoman is this of your acquaintance, sister?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis well dissembled brother, but I know your cunning.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you betrayed me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mum Mr. Mihil, mum.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: Harry, Harry.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: By and by.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: What devil art thou that roarest in mine ear so.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Hold, I beseech you, I come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What, with a by and by, that strikes into my head as sharp as a Stellatto.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I come to tell you, sir, that your table's covered in a fairer room, and more private, your meat is ready to go up, and all in a readiness.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now thou art an honest fellow, there's a couple of shillings for thee. Have us out of thy windmill here, I prithee, and thy by and by's.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter captain Driblow, Clotpoll, Nick, Anthony, drawer, a table, pot and glasses.
div.p: Go sirrah, make your reckoning for our dinner. Leave us this wine, and come when we call you. We have business.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I shall, sir, by and by.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well, sir, you will be of both you say, the blade and the battoon?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Of both, sir, by all means, both Philoblathicus and Philobatticus, I. I'll now have all that belongs to your order, or all my money again, that's for a certain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Your money again? lo you there. You bring me a fit man, gentlemen to be sworn, do you not? that talks of money again, when 'tis a main article in the oath, never to look for money again, once disfingered.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You will not spoil all now 'tis come so far? will you?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Well sir, when I have my oath, and that I am sworn one of you. I'll do as you do, and care as little for money as he that has least.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well, to the oath then, for both the bsade and the battoon you say?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I by all means, captain, for both. 'slid the battoon may stick to me, when the blade may fly out o'th' hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, to the brokers.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Lay your hands on these hilts, sir. The articles that you depose unto are these, to be true and faithful unto the whole fraternity of the blade and the battoon, and to every member thereof.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: As ever faithful member was.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That at no time, wittingly or ignorantly, drunk or sober, you reveal or make discovery of the brother, or a member of the brotherhood, of his lodging, haunts, or by-walks, to any creditor, officer, sutler, or such like dangerous or suspicious person.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I defy them all.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That if any of the brotherhood be in restraint or distress by imprisonment, sickness, or whatsoever engagement, you make his case your own, and your purse and your travel his; and that if a brother die or finish his days, by end timely or untimely, by surfeit, sword, or law. You wear the sable order of the ribbon in remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A convenient cheap way of mourning.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
That your purse and weapon to the utmost
of your strength, be on all occasions drawn to the assistance or defence of a brother or brother's friend, be it he, be it she.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I understand you, and shall be as forward to fight for a she-friend, as ever the best man in the mirror of knighthood was for an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That you be ever at deadly defiance with all such people, as protections are directed to in parliament, and that you watch all occasions to prevent or rescue gentlemen from the gripes of the law brissons. That you may thereby endear yourself into noble society, and drink the juice of the varlet's labours for your officious intrusions.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And that will go down bravely.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You must rank yourself so much the better man, by how much the more drink you are able to purchase at others costs.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You are to let no man take wall of you, but such as you suppose will either beat you or lend you money.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Better and better still.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The rest of your duties for brevity's sake you shall find specified in that copy of your order. Kiss the book.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I'll swear to them whatsoever they be.
So, now I am a blade, and of a better row than those of tytere tu, or oatmeal ho, and so an health to our fraternity, and in chief to our noble captain Driblow.

sp.speaker: Nick. Ant.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Now are you to practise or exercise your quality on the next you meet that is not of the brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Are you one of the brotherhood sir, of the Philoblathici.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I had else lost much sir, I have paid all dues belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So have I as I hope to gain honour by't 40 li. thick at least; yet I have this left, please you command the half sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Another time, your reckoning is not yet paid perhaps.
sp.stage: [Clot. puts his money in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis the first money of mine that was refused since my coming to town. I shall save infinitely.
I see now that I am sworn. How would I swear to get by it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Take heed of that, come hither son.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: How have you screwed this youth up into this humour, that was such a dry miserable clown but two days since.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The old way, by watching of him, and keeping him high-flown a matter of forty eight hours together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Men are apt to believe strange fancies in their liquor, and to entertain new opinions.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have fastened three or four cups upon my precise brother. I would 'twere as many pottles, so it would convert him into the right way of good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would we could see him, to try what good we could do upon him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Perhaps we might convert him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's above still with the old men. I stole from him, but to see if your Italick mistress were come yet. Your madam.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, she comes anon; but is my affliction above still.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thy father? yes

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee do not call him my father less he took better courses.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And so is thy sister; the little rogue looks so squeamishly on me, and I on her, as we had never seen before; but the foolish ape out of a present affection she has taken to my sister, has discovered to her the whole discourse of our love, and my familiarity with thee, which were enough to spoil all, if it were discovered to the old folks, before my cards were played.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, remember Mr. Mihil, you have promised me half, if the old dogged fellow give her all, and you marry her.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou canst not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: You know I can spoil all when I list, but to show my countenance in your cause.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Such is your virtue, sir. Well, I'll up to 'em again before I be missed; and when they part, I am for you again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I have given you all the rudiments, and my most fatherly advices withal.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the last is that I should not swear, how make you that good? I thought now I was sworn into this brotherhood, I might have sworn what, and as much as I would.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That's most unnecessary, for look you son, the best, and even the lewdest of my sons do forbear it, not out of conscience, but for very good ends; and in stead of an oath furnish the mouth with some affected protestation. As I am honest, it is so. I am no honest man if it be not. Ud take me, if I lie to you. Never-go, ne'er stir, l vow, and such like.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or never credit me or let me never be trusted.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: O take heed of that, that may be spoken in so ill an hour, that you may run out of reputation, and never be trusted indeed; the other will gain you credit, and bring you into good and civil estimation with your hostesses; and make 'em term you a fair conditioned gentleman if he had it; and truly I never heard worse word come out of his mouth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Never-go, never-stir, I vow. I'll have, I vow then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow, but you shall not, that's mine.

sp.speaker: Clot
sp.p: Can't you lend it me now and then brother? I'll have, I swear then, and come as nigh swearing as I can.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear but you must not, that's mine you know.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest then, I'll have I protest, that's a city-word, and best to cozen with.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Come boys, fall to some practice, let me see about at the new French balls, sprung out of the old English vapours

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest come on. I'll make a third man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whose man are you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Whose man is not to be asked, nor scarce whose subject, now he is of our brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, by your favour he may ask.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ask no favour, sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: That may be granted.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You can grant nothing in this kind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow he may grant any thing of any kind.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear, I neither can, nor will grant that.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: That, I protest, may bear exception indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Exceptions amongst us? nay, than I vow. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I protest ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Part fair my boys; 'tis very well performed; now drink a round to qualify this bout.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Look upon me ye commonwealth's men now, like a state-surgeon, while I search and try
sp.l: The ulcerous core of foul enormity.
These are a parcel of those venomous weeds,
That rankly pester this fair garden-plot.
Whose boisterous growth is such, that I must use
More policy than strength to reach their root,
And hoist them up at once.
This is my way to get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, 'tis gone round.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I muse these mumpers come not.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Best send a boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Drawer, ha! where be those rascals? (Within) by and by.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are you one of 'em, sir?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I am one that has the favour of the house, sir?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To intrude into gentlemen's privacies? ha!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: To seek a poor living and 't please you, by picking up the crumbs of your liberality, for the use of my rare qualities.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And what's your quality?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It is to speak or sing ex tempore upon any theme, that your fancy or the present occasion shall administer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can you drink before you lay your lips to't

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O my weak eyesight.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or can you eat a crust without chawing, made of the flower of battoon.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good gentlemen, forbear, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The flower of battoon. I protest a good jest, and 'twas mine own before I was aware, for he had the maidenhead or first-blow of my battoon. Nay, it shall down.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will not yet desist; but suffer private affliction with a Roman resolution for the public welfare, with full assurance that my fortitude shall at last get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are not satisfied, it seems, you rascal, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Phew! beat not the poor fellow so.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Let me come to him again, and flesh myself upon him. I will not only flesh myself, but tire upon him.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Enough, enough, good gentlemen, you have beaten me enough of conscience. Was ever good patriot so rudely handled? but the end crowns all.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Forbear him sons. What canst thou be, that canst not be satisfied with beating? speak, art a man or a ghost?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have been, sir, a man, and of my hands, howe'er misfortune humbles me under your manhoods. But I have seen the face of war, and served in the Low-countries, though I say't, on both sides.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Then 'tis impossible this fellow can be beat out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Mick.
sp.p: We'll leave him in his quality for that constant virtue.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sure, 'tis Fenner or his ghost. He was a rhyming soldier. Look, do his eyes stand right?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: They had a dish e'en now, sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Of sack, 'tis true here, take another, and wash the inside of your throat. And let us hear your pipes in their right tune.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Give me a theme gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The praise of sack. Sing the praise of sack.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let it be of the blade.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the battoon, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Do you call, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I will have sack.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Tother quart of Canary? you shall.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are your ears so quick? I vow, I'll dull 'em.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I say, a song of sack.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, let it be of sack.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now you pump, do you?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, sir, but think of a tune.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: If he can pump us up a spring of sack, we'll keep him, and break half the vintners in town.
sp.stage: (Song. Now B. and Clot. asks Gabriel, are you a b‚óèother. They fall in the burden.)

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, well-said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I swear, 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest the best that I have heard in this kind. I wonder at his ability. I prithee, art not acquainted with my two poetical Drury-lane writers? the cobbler and the tapster.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No sir, not I, I work not their way. What I do is ex tempore after the theme given.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But they run quite before you. Their works are in print sometimes ‚ñ™ and ready to be sung about streets, of men that are hanged before they come to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But did not Mihil say he would come again.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I marvel at his stay.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Ay, and the mumpers, when come they? I long to see the sisters, now I am a brother sworn and entered.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O here comes news. How now pig?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: You must all presently to the Paris tavern.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Must? at whose suit!

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Mr. Mihil bade me tell you so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he gone from hence?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: He is, and all his gone and dispersed.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Then the old Jew my father's gone.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Only there's one delicate demure gentleman with Mr. Mihil. travelled along with him towards Paris. I believe he means to make a mouth of him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, 'tis his precise brother. But where's thy mistress, and madama Damaris? that they come not.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: They desire to meet you there too, 'tis more private.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Away we'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Big, how does thy father hog, the Turkey merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: I am in haste, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Turkey merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Because he trades in nothing but Turkey commodities; eggs and concubines; 'twere well to geld him, and send him to the grand signior, to wait in his seraglio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou hast such a wit in this clotpoll of thine. The reckoning drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here, here, sir; here's your bill.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let see the sum. What is't drawer? 40. sh. and 3. d. Si, your dinner, and what you had since, in all, sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis very reasonable, commend me to thy master. Son clotpoll pay't. It is your duty.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, for my brothership.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Boys, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: 40. sh. for four men's dinners, note that, yet he says 'tis reasonable.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Good captain, he was ever the fairest reckoner, though he has never the luck to pay any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fare you well, father.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: When we have further occasion, we'll repair to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: At Bloomesbury. Father, I know.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Bloomsbury? good, I note it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sirrah, look to the second article of your oath.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Against discovery of lodgings, haunts, or by-walks, I am warned.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Look that you be so.

sp.speaker: Nick.
