sp.p: 40. sh. and 3. d. you'll bate the 3. d. will you not?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: We'll not much stand for that sir, though our master sits at dear rent.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Give me your two pieces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let me see the bill before you pay it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, I can hold it then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bread and beer, 1. sh. 4. d. I do not think we four could eat 3. d. of bread, and for my part, I drank but two glasses of beer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And I but one, I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And my father and I but one betwixt us, I protest.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Have you no men below?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Below the earth dost mean? I am sure we have none aboveground.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I know not, gentlemen, there's so much reckoned at the bar, and you please you may see it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, an't be at the bar, it stands for law. Well, wine 5 sh. 9. d. I think we had no less. A shoulder of mutton stuffed with oysters 8. sh. that cost your master very near ten groats, a brace of partridge 5. sh. A couple of cocks 4. sh. 6. d. a dozen of larks 20. d. anchovies 6. sh. I swear but a saucer full.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I'll be sworn they are so much reckoned in the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's law, I tell you, all's law in taverns. But I hope there will be a law for you one o'these days. Then is their fruit and cheese, tobacco, fire, and I know not what, is't right cast.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There is more hope of that young man, then of all the rest, indeed it is a sore abuse, another very weed in the city. I do note that also.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sirrah, before you have your money, fetch me a glass of beer. But canst thou sing this upon any subject.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Any sir, any, an't be till midnight.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But you have strange helps to your invention. I did note the rolling of th' eye, and rubbing your brows sometimes.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So did I, I protest, and therefore, I tell you what. If he can sing such another song, and look steadfastly the while upon any thing, and hold his hands behind him. I'll give him half a crown; if not, he shall ha' nothing for tother.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Agreed gentlemen, give me your theme.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You shall give it him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And withal, watch him if he stir hand or eye, especially the eye.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I will I protest, and set mine eye against his, that he shall not twink, but I'll perceive it, and lay him o'er the pair.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well sir, your theme.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: In praise of the battoon, and if you miss it you shall be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: You'll help me with the burden, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, for the more grace of the song.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take you no care for that. Set your eyes and begin.

lg.l: To prove the battoon the most noble to be.
Of all other weapons observe his degree,
In field to be leader of all other arms,
To conquest and honour, through hazard and harms.
The gallant and peasant, the lord and the loon.
Must move by the motion of the leaders battoon.
The pike and the halbert are subject to it.
The ensign, the partisan, all must submit,
To advance, or retire, fall back, or come on.
As they are directed by the leaders battoon.
Then it is to the soldier the greatest renown,
To purchase by service to bear the battoon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Marry, and take it sir, why do you stare about? though you have broke covenant, I have not.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Where be the gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Ha! they are not gone, I hope, where be my brother's drawer.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Gone sir, and have sent me to you for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest you jest, do you not? I gave 'em the full sum, and all the money I had, I protest, I swear, I vow, now they are not here, I may make bold with their words. They have my money, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: If you have no money, pray leave a pawn, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take him there, put him in a cage, and let him sing it out.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: We know him not, sir.

sp.speaker: Clat.
sp.p: No? he said he had the favour of the house to sing to gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I fear I shall be discovered, sir, I can give your worship credit for a piece till you come to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Protest, thou art generous; nay, I know where to find 'em; and thou shalt go with me to 'em, we will not part now, we'll shoune 'em. I vow, (The words out) here, I'll leave my sword for tother piece.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Your sword will not serve, sir, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take my coat too, a friend and a battoon is better than a coat and a sword at all times.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I am glad my fear is over. And after all my sufferings, if at last
Cock brain crow not these roaring lions down,
Let him be balladed about the town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me now bid you welcome to my father's house, where till your own be fitted, though my father keep too private a family to express large entertainment, yet I hope at worst you shall ha' convenient lodging.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Indeed, I am glad that my father yielded to your father's friendly request in it; and the more, in regard he is so hard to be entreated to any thing; but especially for your society's sake, sweet sister. Indeed I'll call you sister always, and I hope you shall be shortly in my brother Mihil's right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have laid open my heart to you, which indeed is his, but your father, I fear, will never be won.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Why you would not have him too, sister, would you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His consent I would, and my fathers, I hope, would easily be wrought. You saw he was willing your other brother should have me at the first sight, merely for his reservedness, and Mihil methought carried himself as civil today as he; I mean, as civilly for a gentleman, that should not look like one fathers of the Dutch church at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: He was put to't today. The noise of the tavern had almost wrought his zeal into fury, it is scarce out of my head yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you were about to tell me how he first fell into this vein, this vanity indeed.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I'll tell you now, and in that something worth your observation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will observe you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My father has an humour, not to like any thing at first, nor accept best courtesies of friends,
though presently he finds 'em most commodious to him; things that he knows not how to be without, and oftentimes desires with the same breath the things he vilified, and scorned them the last syllable he spoke before. You saw when your father offered him the use of his house here, till his own be furnished, he cried, hah ha! Are all the houses in the town yours sir; and yet presently entreated for't, and thanked him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That shows the best nature, they say.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But that is seldom attended by the best fortune. Nay, in us, I mean, his children, he will like nothing, no, not those actions which he himself cannot deny are virtuous; he will cross us in all we do, as if there were no other way to show his power over our obedience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange fatherly care.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now, note the punishment that follows it. There's not a child he has, though we all know what we do, that make any conscience of crossing him, we have so much of his good nature in us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that's as odd a duty in children.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I must confess it is a stubbornness.

Yet for the most part we do nothing, but that which most parents would allow in their children: and now for my brother Gabriel, with whom I must bring in the story of another kinswoman of ours, my father had at home with us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Nay, mark, I pray you, as I would entreat an auditory, if I now were a poet to mark the plot, and several points of my play, that they might not say when 'tis done, they understood not this or that, or how such a part came in or went out, because they did not observe the passages.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well on, I pray.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My brother Gabriel, when he was a boy, nay,
till within these two years, was the wildest untamed thing that the country could possibly hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he is still for ought I know, for I think no man of his religion in his wits.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mean in outward conversation, he was the ringleader of all the youthful fry, to fairs, to wakes, to may-games, football-matches, any thing that had but noise and tumult in it; than he was captain of the young train-band, and exercised the youth of twenty parishes in martial discipline. O he did love to imitate a soldier the best, ‚Äî and so in every thing, that there was not an handsome maid in an whole county could be quiet for him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He may be good at that sport still, for there is almost none of his sect holds any other game lawful.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet did he bear the civilest and the best ordered affection to our kinswoman I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, I remember.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: So loving to her person, so tender of her honour that nothing but too near affinity of blood could have kept them asunder.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And she did love him as well!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O dear, virtuously well; but my father fearing what youth in heat of blood might do, removes my brother Gabriel from home into the service of a reverend Bishop to follow good examples.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But he learned not to be a Puritan there I hope.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
You shall hear, sister, soon after came a gallant into the country from London here, and as we after found, a citizen's son, though he showed like a lord there. Briefly, he grew acquainted with my brother Mihil. Then woo'd and won my
cousin so secretly, my father never suspected, nor he nor I e'er knew whose son he was, nor of what occupation my old lord his father was; but he promised her marriage, clapped her, you may guess where, and so like the slippery Trojan left her.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: O devilish rascal!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And foolish creature, she who soon repented it, and with her shame is fled to what part of the world we know not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth 'tis pitiful, that villain would be hanged.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now upon this, my poor brother that loved her so, fell into discontent, forsook his lord, and would have left the land, but that he was prevented and brought home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ever since he has been thus religious.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Thus obstinate, for I think verily he does it but to cross my father, for sending him out of the way when the mischief was done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will not then believe 'tis religion in any of the gang of 'em, but mere wilful affectation. But why, or wherein do you or Mihil. cross your father.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I tell you sister we must. He is so cross himself, that we shall never get any thing of him that we desire, but by desiring the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then do you desire him to get you an husband?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Because he should get me none. O sister, both he and Mr. cockbrayne, can wish now that I had had his son.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There's another youth now gone on love's pilgrimage, e'er since your father crosthim in your love not to be heard of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Hush! the old men.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: In good truth sir, I am taken with your conversation. I like it now exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I'm glad it pleases you.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: 'Tis very fair and friendly, I find we shall accord.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad I have it for you sir, I pray, make bold with it.

sp.speaker: Ro‚óèk.
sp.p: Then pray sir, let me urge my motion a little further to you.

sp.speaker: Cros,
sp.p: What is't? you cannot utter it so easily as I shall grant it, out with it man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That you will be pleased to accept my daughter for either of your sons, your youngest if you please, now I have seen him, I'll give him with her presently, either in hand a thousand pound, and five hundred pound a child as fast as he can get 'em. And all I shall die seized of.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What a dogbolt is this to think that I should get a child for him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope you do think well on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray love he does. I hope so too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mark his answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could find in my heart to ask his goodwill myself.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And that were a sure way to go without it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: How say you, sir, is't a match?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will not stay a minute in thy house, though I lie in the street for't.
Housewife, I'll sort you with fitter companions, come, follow me quickly.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven bless me and my child too from matching with such a disposition.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truly, sir, I longed to be out oh th' house before.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Before you came in it did you not? ha!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: These new walls do so stink of the lime methinks.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Marry fough, goody foist.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: There can be no healthy dwelling in 'em this twelvemonth yet.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you so tender bodied?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Even please yourselves then where you can like better, and you shall please me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why you will not thrust me out of your house, will you? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: There's no such haste, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Indeed there is not, nor will I out for all your haste neither. I'll have look to my bargain.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But no more of your idle motions, if you love your ease in your house, your ‚óè‚óèn here.
Here's a letter, sir, from Mr. cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is the earer paid, or give him that an't please you.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: somebody has angered him, and I must suffer.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I sent you to seek my sons, good sir, have you found 'em? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I cannot find 'em sir. They went out of the tavern together, they say, and I have been at Mr. Mihil's chamber, and there they are not. I went to the tavern again, and there they were not. Then I beat all the rest o'th' bushes, in this four forest of fools and mad men, and cannot find 'em I, where'er they be.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Sirrah, go find 'em me where'er they be, anywhere , or nowhere , find 'em, and find 'em
quickly; I'll find 'em in your coxcomb else, do ye see! and bring my son's sanctity home before it be dark, lest he take up his lodging in a church-porch; and charge Mr. Mihil that he come not to me till I send for him. Here's danger i'th' house. There was a match-motion indeed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good sir, either like my house well, or be pleased to please yourself with some better.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Pray sir, be quiet in your house, lest I send you out of it to seek another. Let me see my chamber.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: He must have his way, I see.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Betty, Frank, with swords drawn make fast the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: Nay, you perpetual puss, I'll fetch him out of the very bowels of thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He never came so deep himself yet with all that he could do, and I scorn the threatening of a she marmoset.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why Betty, Frank, you mankind carrions you. I vow, open the door, will you both kill one another, and cozen the hangman of his fees?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Thou hadst been better have bit off the dugs of thy dam, thou pin-buttock jade thou, than have snapped a bit of mine from me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here's that shall stay your stomach better than the bit you snarl for. Thou greedy brach thou.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why wenches, are ye wild? break open the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That I could split that devilish tongue of thine!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have as good a spite at as ill a member about thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hold, what's the devil in ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are ye so sharp-set ye Amazonian trulls?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Let me but make one pass at her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray let me go, and let her come.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can no blunter tools than these serve to take down your furies?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Let me come but within nails reach of her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me but try the strength of my teeth upon her.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: As Hector 'twixt the hosts of Greece and Troy,
When Paris and the Spartan King should end
Their nine years wars, held up his brazen lance.
In signal, that both armies should surcease,
And hear him speak. So let me crave your audience.
Dear Betty be advised, and Frank, forbear
Thy thirst of sister's blood. Whilst I rip up
The folly of your strife. Your cases both
Have been laid open to me. You contend
For love of a lewd citizen, that sleights,
Nay more, disdains, nay more, defies you both.
Tony can tell, Mun clotpoll also knows
The words he spoke, that you were both poor whores,
Not poor alone, but foul infectious harlots.
And that he wears your mark with pain and sorrow,
Hopeless to claw them off. With constant purpose
Never to see you more, unless to greet.
Your bumpin buttocks with revengeful feet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Did he say so?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And must we two fall out for such a slanderous villain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, agree, agree.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Buss and be friends. Buss, or I'll baste ye both, I vow.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come sister we'll be in for ever now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For my part, sister, sure I was not out with you.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But did he say he would kick us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lo here, the man that dares it not deny.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: But do ye hear, gentlemen. I hope you will use me kindlier than so.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Than how, sir?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Then to win all my money, and leave me at stake for the reckoning. Pray do you pay the drawer for me, though I pay it you again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is it drawer?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: The gentlewomen and he had 14. sh. in before you came.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Tis a plain case, your cloak must answer it at the bar, sir. Drawer, away with it.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Nay, but gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do but look after it, till we be gone, and these shall claw thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Well sir, I hope this quarter will not be always lawless.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you grumble? Mr. cuffeless.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow you shall have cuffs.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, that you shall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cuts and slashes too before we part, sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: You will not murder me, will you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Damosels forbear; and you, forbear your noise. I vow, I'll slit your whistle else. You shall give him due correction civilly, and we will make him take it civilly. Sit you down sir.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: What will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, mum.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O, are ye here! was it a brotherly trick do ye think, to leave me to pay one reckoning twice? or did I think never to be made a mouth more, after I had paid my swearing dinner, and am I now a greater mouth than e'er I was?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mum, hold your tongue still in your mouth, lest I halifax it with your teeth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Halifax my tongue. And listen to a business.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Do yond know this man?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, the city mouth we had tother night.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: These are the sisters that his lavish tongue so lewdly did deprave.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I cry them heartily mercy are you of the sweet sisterhood? I hope to know you all, all the pretty mumpers in the berry here, before I have done. 'tis true, I protest, he spoke words of you, that such flesh and blood could not bear. He could not have spoken worse of mutton of a groat a quarter.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And were we so fond to fight for him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But now we'll both be revenged upon the flesh of him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Pray let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, they shall beat you first. And mark me well. Do thou but stir an hand or foot, or raise a voice that may be heard to the next room, well cut thy weasand. Now wenches take your course.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, you slave, we'll mark you for a sheep-biter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll teach you how to scandalize.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Have I given you that you cannot claw off, you mongrel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Rare, I protest.

sp.speaker: Ciot.
sp.p: ‚Äî o ‚Äî o ‚Äî o.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There, there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll claw thine ears off rather.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: ‚Äî o ‚Äî o ‚Äî o.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O brave.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O outrage, most insufferable, all this goes into my black book.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To him Betty, at him Frank; their whores, there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, fie, forbear, enough, too much in conscience.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: That young man has some pity yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I swear you shall no more.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Alas, good gentlemen, it is enough.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do you prate? you shall have as much. Come, take the chair, sir, the breeches shall bait him too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, they shall. To him and claw him, I'll clapperclaw your sides else

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O me! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Heyday! his beard comes off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And his head too what rotten scab is this?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest, they have pulled my pieced brother in pieces here.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, some disguised villain, and but for doing the state so good service, we would hang him presently without examination.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know him. And you shall not touch him. Best is, he knows nor me. Good heaven, what braintrick has possessed him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, what canst thou be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, 'tis an honest fellow, that is only ashamed to run so base a course for his living in his own face. Poor man, I warrant his fear threatens his breeches shrewdly. But let's away, and quickly, our stay is dangerous. Come, we forgotten Mich Croswil and the wenches.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come all away then, sirrah, thank this gentleman, and pray for him at the end of your songs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Farewell, friend piece. I'll know you better now, before you have't again.
sp.stage: Ex. omnes but cock. and Cit.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What monsters in mankind? what hellhounds are they? only as Ovid feigned among the Getes. A friend at need, I with a friend was blessed, whom I may gratify, and plague the rest. How is it with you, sir?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: O, I am very sore.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Indeed you are sorely handled. This may warn you out of such caterwaling company. You look like one more civil. And in hope you will be so, I'll bring you to a barber.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Alas, my cloak.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'll help you to that too, so you with me, will in an honest plot assistant be.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: O sir, in any thing, and thank you too, sir.

div.head: Scoen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Mihil, Gabriel, boy, wine, etc.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A Paris ill ya ben veni - here's no bush at this door, but good wine rides post upon't, I mean, the signpost. Boy, get you down, and if Nick Rooksbill, or any of his company ask for me, bring 'em up, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will, I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are welcome to Paris brother Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is nevertheless a tavern, brother Mihil, and you promised and covenanted with me at the last house of noise and noisomeness, that you would not lead me to any more taverns.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Lead you brother? men use to be led from taverns sometimes. You saw I did not lead you nor bring you to any that was more a tavern than the last, nor so much neither; for here is no bush you saw.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Twas that betrayed and entrapped me: but let us yet forsake it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray let us drink first brother. By your leave here's to you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: One glass-full more is the most that I can bear. My head is very full, and laboureth with that I have had already.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There sir, I'll undertake one good fellow, that has but just as much religion as will serve an honest man's turn, will bear more wine than ten of these giddy-brained Puritans, their heads are so full of whimsies.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Tis mighty heady, mighty heady, and truly I cannot but think that the over much abuse of these outlandish liquours, have bred so many errors in the Romish church.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Indeed brother, there is too much abuse made of such good creatures. Wine in itself is good, you will grant, though the excess be naught; and taverns are not contemptible, so the company be good.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is most true, we find that holy men have gone to taverns, and made good use of 'em upon their peregrinations.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
And cannot men be content to take now and
then a cup, and discourse of good things by the way. As thus. Brother, here's a remembrance (If she be living, and have not lost her honour) to our cousin door as.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O that kinswoman of ours. She was the dearest loss that e'er fell from our house.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Pledge her, good brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I do ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope 'twill maudlenize him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: But have you never seen that miscreant that wronged her, since he did that same, they say you knew him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Alas, suppose I had, what could be done? she's lost we see. What good could she receive by any course against him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It had been good to have humbled him, though into the knowledge of his transgression. And of himself for his souls good, either by course of law, or else in case of necessity, where the law promiseth no relief, by your own right hand you might have smote him, smote him with great force, yea, smote him unto the earth, until he had prayed that the evil might be taken from him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This is their way of loving enemies, to bear 'em into goodness. Well, brother, I may meet with him again, and then I know what to do. If he knew him as I do now, what a religious combat were here like to be at nicks coming.
Sir, here's a gentlewoman asks for Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The travelled gallant, is't not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, and the old black party, her land lady with her. But they ask for nobody but him, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say he is here by all means, and bring 'em up.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Women! pray brother let's avoid the place, let us fly it. What should we do with women in a tavern?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: No harm assure yourself, cannot we govern ourselves?
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas and Madge, and start back.

sp.speaker: Nay,
sp.p: Lady, stay, he will be here presently, that you look for.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will not glance an eye towards temptation.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I am amazed sure, I have seen this face, howe'er your habit and the course of time may give't another seeming.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Good angels, help my thoughts and memory. It is my kinsman Mihil. What's the other that hides his face, so?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Do you turn away?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: It is my cousin Gabriel, strangely altered.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Come hither you. I'll make a little bold with you. Thou that hast been a concealer of more sins in women's actions, than thou hast grizzled hairs.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sure I will speak to him, he always loved me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Reveal a truth to me on my demand, now instantly, without premeditation. I'll cut thy tongue out else.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's here to do? do you think I am a devil? that you make such conjurations over me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I think thou art as true a servant of his as any bawd can be. But he now if thou darest. How long have you known that gentlewoman? and what do you know by her?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Here's a stir about nothing. I know nothing by her, not I. Nor whether she has any thing or nothing, that a woman should have by the report of knowledge of man, woman or beast, not I. She came to me but this morning, with a purpose to set me up in my new house as I hoped. But she has taken a course to make it honestly spoken of already, to my utter undoing, but she never comes within my doors again, as I hope to thrive by my trade hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Pray look upon me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Was she so resolutely bent, and so soon altered?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Upon the very first fight of the very first man that came into my house, the very first hour of my setting up in it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What man was that?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A shame take him, your roaring friend, Nick. I think she is enamoured of him, or of something she guesses he has; and would fain play the honest woman with him, that never played honest man with woman in his life.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Tis she, and 'tis most wonderful.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: If you knew who I were, you would not be so strange to me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And here she comes me a hunting after him, like a fondling, whilst half a dozen pieces might ha' been gotten at home by this time, and she have had the halves of it in her purse by this time; if she would have done, as I thought, she would have done by this time.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Alas, poor owlet.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I sent whooping after the best guest that haunt my house, to have taken the first fruits of her conversation, and she would not see a man of 'em, to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well leave thy hooting, Madge, and hold thy peace. thou shalt get by it.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Yes, I shall get a good name shortly, and this gear hold, and turn beggar, I shall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray sir, but one word.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Speak to her, brother, 'tis our cousin Dorcas.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Will you abuse me too? is she not lost?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And will not you give her leave to be found again? his wine and her sudden apprehension works on him at once. Cousin, I'll speak to you, though I confess the miracle of our meeting thus amazes me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O cousins both. As ye are gentlemen, and of that noble stock, whose mere remembrance, when he was given up, and at the brink of desperate folly, stroke that reverend fear into my soul, that hath preserved my honour from further falling. Lend me now your aid, to vindicate that honour by that man, that threw me in the way of loss and ruin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All shall be well, good cousin, you shall have both hands and hearts to re-estate you in him. So that in fact you have not wronged that honour, since he forsook you.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: On my soul I have not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Infants then shall be pardoned. Brother speak.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You were wont still to be my lovingest cousin.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What a strange dream has wine wrought in my head.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I hope it will work out his superfluous zeal.
And render him civil christian again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is no dream, good cousin, you are awake,
And I, that Dorcas, for whom you have wished

Affinity of blood might be dispensed with. And you
to be my choice. So well you loved me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And will above my life affect you still. But you must leave these gauds and profane dressings.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Bawds did he say? how comes he to know me trow?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.l: How came my cousin Gabriel thus translated.
Out of gay clothes long hair, and lofty spirit,
Stout and brave action, manly carriage;
Into so strict a reformation?
Where is the martial humour he was wont so to affect.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: His purity and your disgrace fell on you both about a time, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do you swear by your faith?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's falling back again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Some more wine. You will drink with our
Cousin, brother, will you not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What wine is't, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, in a cup of sincere love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What other wine you please, gentlemen, we have none such i'th 'House.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Of the same we had, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Call not for wine for us, cousin.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Assuredly, we are no profane wine-bibbers, not we.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Modest, and well-spoken verily, she should be a sister or a matron.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we'll all drink for the good o'th' house.
'Tis upon putting down, they say, and more o'th neighbours. But cousin, he knew you not today.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, nor dreams of me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And the old one knows nothing, does she.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: No, by no means.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: She can bewray nothing then. My brother knows not him. I only do for his fair sister's sake, of which you may hear more hereafter; in the mean, bear yourself fair and free, as if you knew him not, and I'll work him to your end, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You are a noble spokesman.
sp.stage: [bawd and Gabriel confer devoutly the while.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Truly, you speak most edifyingly.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well-said, give it to my brother. Drink to our cousin, brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will, and to that virtuous matron, whose care of her, I hope, tends unto good edification. ‚Äî truly the wine is good, and I was something thirsty.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Best drink again then, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will follow your motherly advice.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill work, anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And you have travelled cousin. I may suppose you brought this well-disposed gentlewoman from Amsterdam with you. And this unto your welcome, hoping I shall be informed by you how the two zealous brothers thrive there? that broke in st. Helen's.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Of that or any thing sir, pray drink again, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You jade you, hold your tongue.
sp.stage: Enter Nick, Anthony, Clotpoll, Betty, Frank.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, are ye here gallants! I made all the haste I could, but was stayed, I vow, by the bravest sport, baiting of a fellow or two with our pusse-cats here. I could e'en find in my heart to marry 'em both for their valours.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Those words are daggers.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I pray dissemble your passion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What? are you acquainted already?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee she was a brave madonna?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: How long have you had acquaintance with her, Nick?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Never saw her before this morning, ay, standing upon her balcony.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly cousin, I think 'twas you that I saw today too, standing upon a Bellconee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: You spell very modestly, sir. Your brother
I take it. But did you call her cousin, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes sir, she is my cousin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill out too soon. Why Nick, thou knowest these kind of creatures call and are called cousins commonly.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, in their tribe. But I thought he had been too holy for them. But Dammy ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O fearfully profane!

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You said you had a story to relate, of dire misfortune. and of uncouth hearing. I come to hear your story, what stop you your ears at? sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I dare not speak it but in thy reproof. Thou swearest gee uh dee, d'ye arm thee, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thou liest, I called her Dammy, because her name is Damyris,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I say thou liest, her name is Dorcas, which was the name of an holy woman.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Shall we have things and things? I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I protest.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This will spoil all. Brother, I pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I may not forbear, I am moved for to smite him; yea, with often stripes to smite him; my zealous wrath is kindled, and he shall fly before me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bet. Frank.
sp.p: What fury's this?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Great Damboys shrink, and give a little ground.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will pursue him in mine indignation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And beat him into potsherds.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Now he has banged the pitcher, he may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray, brother, be persuaded.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A brother to be so controlled?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You sir, put up your steel-stick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I desire but to know first, if he be a brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes marry is he, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Sir, I am satisfied. So let him live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to ask you, do these men take part with the brothers?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and are brothers a little disguised, but for some ends.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Some state-occasions.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Mere intelligencers, to collect up such and such observations, for a great separatist that is now writing a book against playing at barleybreak, moulding of cocklebread, and such like profane exercises.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly such exercises are profane exercises, that bear the denomination of good things ordained for man's use, as barley, cockles, and bread are such things to be made sports and play-games? I pray you let me see these brothers again, to make my atonement with them. And are those sisters too, that were with them?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
O, most notorious ones, and are as equally disguised to be as rank spies as the other. 'slid man, and they should be taken for such as they are, they would be cut off presently. They came in this
mad humour to be merry with you for my sake.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray let 'em come again, I shall not be well until I have rendered satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You must do as they do then, or they will think you are a spy upon them.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will be as merry as they, let wine be given unto us.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: More wine, boy, and bid 'em all come in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, cousin, let him drink no more.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Fear nothing, cousin, it shall be for his good and yours, as I will order it.
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Anthony, Clotpoll, Betty, Frank, drawer with wine

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All welcome, not any repetition, but begin a new

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will begin it, two glasses: it shall be a faithful salutation to all the brothers and sisters of ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The blade and the scabbard.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It shall go round.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll swear you do not well to let him drink so.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well said civil roarer.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Let it go round, go to, you are a wag. I know what you mean by the blade and the scabbard.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Who could have thought this had been such a brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Nay, who could have thought you had been of the brothers.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brethren sir, we are the brothers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yea, the disguised ones.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: How? disguised ones?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Do not cross him again. If thou dost, and I do not maul thee. Yes, brother, these are virtuous
men howe'er they seem.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I have so much virtue as to rebuke thee for lying. But we are brothers, sir, and as factious as you, though we differ in the grounds; for you, sir, defy order, and so do we; you of the church, we of the civil magistrate; many of us speak i'th' nose, as you do; you out of humility of spirit, we by the wantonness of the flesh; now in devotion we go beyond you, for you will not kneel to a ghostly father, and we do to a carnal mistress.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'll stop your mouth, you said you came to be merry.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, and brought fiddlers along, but they must play i'th' next room, for here's one breaks all the fiddles that come in his reach. Come fir, will you drink, dance, and do as we do?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'll drink, I'll dance, I'll kiss, or do any thing, any living thing with any of you that is brother or sister. Sweetheart let me feel thy coney.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I now he's in. Play fiddlers. Dance.
All bravely performed, admirably well done, etc.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, thou art a brother after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.p: We cannot commend you enough, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This done in civil fort among ourselves, I hope, will prove no scandal to a brother.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Twill prove an honour to our faction.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I thirst to do it honour.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Give him some wine, he thirsts.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Thou little dapper thing, thou, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou seest he can scarce stand.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, my religious brothers, no more wine.
Enough's a feast, and little doth suffice.
sp.p:
I thirst to do some honour to our cause. To lead
forth legions to fight a battle 'gainst our. malignant adversaries.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brave.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such an employment now would make me famous, for my sufficiency of Att in arms.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, this man has hidden things in him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He has as brave a warlike spirit, man, before his precise humour tainted it, as ever breathed in Hector.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow then, a good orderly diet of nothing but sack for a week together, would revive it in him, and bring it to good again.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I hope, 'tis done already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How do you, sit?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I fear some jesuitical fumes have invaded my brain pan. All methinks goes whirley, whirley, whirley.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Best lie down upon a bed. Drawer!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Soldier's must not be curious. A bench or any thing.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: The gentleman may have a bed here, an't please you. But sir, there's an old angry gentleman below, that asks for you, and by all description for that mortified gentleman. And will by all means press into your room here.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is my father.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O me! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: M‚óèd. Bet. Fran.
sp.p: We shall be all clapped up.

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.p: Fear nothing, veil your face a little; who is with him?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: nobody but his old servingman, that it seems discovered you. You may put this gentleman into this inner room, and keep the key yourself. I know not what charge he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Admirable honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: And you may tell your father he is gone, for he is gone you see.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow. A wit.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Now if you'll be civil, I may bring him up to you, if not, because he is your father, we'll thrust him out of doors, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Notable rascal, well sir, let him up. I know how to fit him.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: But this delays my business, cousin, and will, I fear, frustrate my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor hinder any thing, I'll warrant thee, he's thine. Play fiddlers, tother dance.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Will you! protest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not wild?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come wenches, if he venture in his father's sight, shame take us and we blush.

sp.speaker: Cross. belt.
sp.p: And I had not sold all my land to live upon my money in town here, out of danger or the statute, I would give thee a copyhold for this discovery.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank your worship, and truly 'tis a goodly sight, methinks , an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I'm glad it likes you. Heigh, excellent good again. Heigh, heigh, what an happiness may fathers boast, that can bring their children up to this. (Dance ended)I cry ye mercy, gentlemen all. Ha! I am sorry I interrupted your serious private occasions.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, sir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It is my father, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Thy father? hold thy peace; dar'st thou use thy father thus? to spend thy time thus! ha! Is this place fit for the son of a gentleman of quality? ha! why dost not answer me, does this company sort with thy reputation? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, the company. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, I say, or are these exercises allowable for a gentleman, that ever said or heard grace at his father's table? answer me that.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: An't please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hold thy peace when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The company, sir, offends not you, I hope; you see the worst of us.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: In good time, sir, you are the distracted gentlemen, I take it, that asked him if he would moot tonight ? Is this your mooting? do you put cases to your wenches, or they to you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thy father talks too much.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Which are the better lawyers? ha!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But that you are his father, sit, and an old man, and he an honest young gentleman, and our friend, we would tell you.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I thank you for him, yes truly, heartily; and for your good opinion of him, heartily. Pray keep him amongst you while ye have him, for I'll ha' no more to say to him, I. Is your invectives against drinking, wenching, and the abomination of the times come to this? is this your spending of time more precious than money? is it you that knows not what to do with money but to buy books; and were drawn with such unwillingness to a tavern? ha! you shall graze upon Littleton's commons, or eat nothing but books, an't please you, for any exhibition thou ever gettest from me ‚Äî and in that faith thou hast lost a father. Come sir, you have brought me to a goodly sight here; would any villain but thyself have showed his master light to see so much woe! Thy coxcomb shall yet pay for't.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O sir, o.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: This was your trim sight, was it?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But well remembered. Pray where's your brother? my son I would say; for I know no brother or father thou hast. Where is Gabriel?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He is not here, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Did you not tell me, sirrah, he was here?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I told you then too much. I feel it here.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He was here, sir, but he is gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: So, so, he's lost. He must be cried, or we shall never find him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, I'll find him yet tonight , sir. Pray gentlemen pay you the reckoning, I'll wait upon my father home.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Was that spoke like a son of mine? must others pay your reckoning, and I in place; take that, and do not make me mad. And why should you home with me? I pray, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Because sir, it grows dark, and 'tis the worst way as it is about the town; so many odd holes a man may slip into; pray take me with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Pray take no care for me, sir, and let the way be as it is. Do not think me worse at it in the dark than yourself, I beseech you. But you talked of the reckoning, pray let not the want of money for that hinder the search of your brother. There's towards your pains for that; and so for a farewell to you and your friends here, till I hear thou keepest better company, let me hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There was no way to get this money, and be rid of him, but to offer him my service he would have driven me out before him else. But come, let's see my brother that went to sleep in so warlike a passion. I hope he'll wake in a better.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mun clotpoll, thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No, I protest, but struck with admiration at the old blade's humour.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come, Dammy and the rest, be merry. I vow, we'll sup together, and so at last hear all thy dismal story.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I mean he shall, and such an audit make,
As shall restore her honour from the stake.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
What has this coxcomb cockbrayne written me here? That he desires his absence be excused. What have I to do with him? when I send for him, let him come to me. That he is upon a point of discovery in a most excellent project for the weeding of this garden? what garden? what project? A project he says here for the good of the republic, repudding. This fellow has in stead of brains, a cobweb in his noddle, with little straws, feathers, and wings of dead butterflies hanging in it, that having motion by his airy fancy, there dance and keep a racket; 'tis to teach women silence, or some such foolish impossibility. He is ambitious to be called into authority by notice taken of some special service he is able to do the tate aforehand. But what great service he is able to do it, or which way to undertake it, falls not in the reach of my imagination. But good Mr. Croswill, by your favour now, what reason have you to slight or wrangle at this man? this honest cockbrayne? that has always been a constant friend to you, and officious in many good ways, and is a gentleman, not only of good descent and estate, but of a good disposition. And you two, Mr. Crosswill, by your leave, have always agreed like
neighbours' children. Ay, the devil was in't, and now he vexes me again; we agreed in one point so well, that we have undone a couple of our children by it, and hindered the getting of I know not how many more. His son and my daughter should have married. And on a sudden he and I both consented to a dislike of the match and broke it, and have both repented it an hundred times since. We agree very well in that point; and now is his son irrecoverably lost, and my daughter resolutely bent to be an ape-leader in limbo. But what's all this to the affliction I suffer in my sons now? that one of them from a riotous boy. should grow into a puritanical woodcock; and the tother from a civil well-qualified fellow, turned absolute ruffian. There, there, I there's the devil in't. I could beat myself for getting such children.
See, see, my master for want of other company fallen out with himself, and it please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It does not please me, nor thou pleasest me, nor any thing pleases me. The world's bent to cross me, and thou shalt feel it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O good sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Is it not so, sir, was not that dunce Gabriel, a most notorious wild thing

Before he steered a religious course? but then he run so full a sail, that he passed and was beyond the line of religion before he was aware; and as he passed it under the torrid zone of zeal, the calenture took him o'the pate, that he is mad with it, and as far beyond religion now as it is to it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Sir, there's hope that he may he fetch't half way back again, by your fatherly advice, and become a sound man.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And then was not Mihil so civil, that he made me even sick to see him. And now is he flown out as far into riot tother way.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: But he, sir, will appear a present comfort to you, he is reclaimed already; you shall never see such a reformation in a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What's this you tell me? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: He has cast off his long-curled hair and all.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.l: He had been better have cut his head off.
Where is he!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Below sir, and a gentlewoman with him, but very much afraid to appear to you. I never saw a man so timoursome.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Do you think it fit I should go down to him, or he come up to me, fir, ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I'll fetch him, here's a life!

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I charged he should not come at this house too, for fear he might be catched with this mechanic fellows daughter, though her portion be around one. And let him take heed he look not at her.
Bless me! what changeling is this? he's in his brother's cut.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, ‚Äî sir. ‚Äî

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, sir, do you know me. I know not you, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The sense of your late displeasure, sir, has so humbled me into the knowledge of myself, that on the wings of true obedience, I flew after you to make a child's submission at your feet, to crave your pardon for my riotous transgression, and to ask your blessing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
A delicate speech, pray take it for fashion-sake.
But if I know how to look towards thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray sir, bestow it really upon me.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: God bless thee, I say, and so much many honest men bestow daily on sons that are none of their own, if thou beest mine, how camest thou thus like a fellow that had narrowly 'scaped the pillory, and bragged in the publication of his ears? not an hair left to hide them.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: To show my readiness to reform my life, sir. And yet a willingness withal to live, as well, as civilly, in which I am in all humility to prefer a suit to you. You know, sir, I am but a younger brother.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Here is a widow, sir, a gentlewoman of great estate, and of a well-known life. Ancient she is, and has had husbands. How many?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Four truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Four sir, I would not lie. Of which the worst spoke well of her on's deathbed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's that to me or thee? come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I have all would and won her, sir, and crave but your goodwill to marry her. I have brought a churchman and a kinsman to give her.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Why so, what needs two words then? do you think I can deny you?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: If he does grant it, 'tis the first request that e'er he granted in his life. Sure the old matchmaker the devil thinks I am in earnest to marry this beast. And puts a readiness in his hand to forward it.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Widow, you are welcome. Why call you not your priest? or tarry sir, let me question you but a little, do you think seriously you love this widow?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Better then many men love their wives, I am persuaded.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, what children have you widow?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Never had any, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Very well still.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor ever like to have any, fir, that's the comfort. We shall live at the less charge.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Thou art a covetous and a preposterous knave. Wouldst thou bury up thy youth in barren ground? dost seek after wealth, and not after issue? dost love to feed on other men's leavings? or travel only in a beaten path? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A man goes certainest on his journey so, sir, and less trouble it is you know to go in at a great gate, than a narrow wicket.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: You have said enough, sir, and delight to cross me; but I'll cross you for once, and lay a cross upon you, shall perhaps carry you to your grave. Go, fetch your priest.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'll face it as far as I dare. I hope I shall have the grace to pull my hand from the book when it comes so far.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Widow, you are resolved to have him too.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Before all men i'th' world by your fair leave, 1.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: You shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Without your free consent, I will not.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I am resolved I'll do't. And 'twill be the best cross trick that e'er I did in my life. Pray let me speak in some more private with you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: If I but escape Bridewell, I care not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Now Tony, she's thine own, now sister Kate;
he's thine. The priest has pronounced it. I say, amen to't. And heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now you have done the best brotherly office that ever made a sister happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And the friendliest to a friend. We have been casting for it, sweet, this twelvemonth, and heaven pardon me. I vowed never to take acquaintance of my father, till 'twere effected. Although I know of late he has been willing.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And so is mine, I know, but yet he swore, that I should match myself before he knew't, or I should never marry.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You'll find him of another mind towards me, and force me into wedlock presently.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: You have taken the likeliest course that could be. But what is your disguised woman, brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What you shall never know, sister, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Come sir, I have broken off the match with your widow; and she's content to leave you as she found you. And now take me this pretty, simpering, plump-lipped, ruddy-cheeked, white-necked, long-fingered virgin in hand, or I will swinge you, sirrah, look to't. If you cannot live civilly with a young wife, you cannot but be mad with an old, I think. Besides, she's a friend's daughter of mine, and prepared by her discreet father here to love you. Come, and kiss her, quickly, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I cannot do't for all the wealth in the world.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Kiss a maid I never saw above twice in my life.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He will have me think him a bastard, do I what I can. Canst thou see a maid twice, and not kiss her?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, twenty times, sir, and not kiss her, or if once, not above, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But you shall kiss her above and below, sir, and in every room o'th' house, sir, before you part. Stand fair pretty one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not how to do't.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You were not best let me instruct you. I can be angry too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His back side's towards me.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Turn yourself, sirrah, or I'll turn you. Go to, bend your body a little and be hanged. So, now come your way, and say after your little sir John here, I Mihil take thee, Lucy, etc. As learning shall enable him to proceed without book.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Pray let 'em do it in the next chamber, they are too bashful afore us. There are witnesses enough. Go all in, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Widow, will you give me leave to obey my father?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: With all my heart, and say amen to the marriage.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I think I shall have my will at last upon one of my rebellious offspring.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And now, pray give me leave sir, to let you know how happy I do hold myself in this marriage. I did like this son better than the other before. And now I like him better than I did at my former view of him, by some reformation that I do observe in him. And I do not a little rejoice in the honour I may have to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
That very word brother out of his mouth, has turned my stomach. I must pull all in pieces again. And yet let me see these young bloods when they
are set on't; if they do not marry, they will do worse. Let 'em e'en go on now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You may easily conceive, sir, what a comfort it will be unto me, that I now growing old, and having (I give praise for't,) wealth enough, and no child that I make account of but this one daughter, may, before I die, see grandchildren that I may have by her sufficiently provided for, be they more or less in number, they may have enough.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: There he is again, he calls my grandchildren that shall be, his grandchildren. Am I a gentleman, and can hear this? if it be not too late, I'll spoil the getting of your grandchildren.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven give you joy. Heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: I do pronounce them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mad. Kat. And we are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.p: What remedy?

sp.speaker: Mih. Luc.
sp.p: We are, and crave your blessings.

sp.speaker: Cross. Rook.
sp.p: All blessings be upon you, (All salute).

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But you, sir, Mr. bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'll only gratify the minister.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Do so, and pay him well, it is, perhaps, for the dearest fault that e'er thou didst.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There's for your pains, sir. Madge, there's for you. Enough to purchase thee a licence to sell ale, tobacco, and strong-water again in Godpiece-rowe, for here will be no dwelling for thee, I see that.

Now, brother Anthony, go you all back to the company we left, and see that my instructions be followed
concerning my brother Gabriel, Nick, and his dammie,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Shall he go from me?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, but you shall follow him presently, trust to me sister. Go, take no leave of 'em. I'll bring 'em upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Are you at leisure now, sir, to tell me of your brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, to my grief, sir, praying you may have patience.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: To your grief, sir, he is not dead then? Younger brothers seldom grieve for their elders death.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray bear it as you may, sir I left him in an heavy plight. And let me speak it with sorrow, he lay speechless.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Alack-a day, good gentleman, my son in-law, perhaps, is heir already.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And hast thou been here all this while fooling or wiving (All's a matter) and left thy brother in danger? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He's well attended, sir, and looked unto. Nor would I wish you see his weak estate.
It can but grieve you, sir, my wife and sister, together with myself, will go. Or if
It please my father Rooksbill here, because his power in this quarter is available.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Go, show the way. I'll go in person, I. My son's my son.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Nay, pray sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Yes, 'cause you have a wife, you shall control me. Will you go on, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well, I'll bring you to him, sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was your widow, sir, she stunk of aquavitae, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'll tell thee as we go. Kiss.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What a drunken sot was I, that knew thee not all this while? I vow, thy story pities me. I'll marry thee, and turn thee to thy friends, for I am sure I have none that will keep thee for my sake.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: I ask no further satisfaction of you, than to be honested by marriage. I'll work for a poor living.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee Mun seek me a priest.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I have no acquaintance in their function, I.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: My cousin Mihil said he would bring or send one.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There's no starting, that Mihil has a fist over me. I vow, and thou wert not his kinswoman, thou should to the common yet.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Father, how come you hither?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Did not the company send for me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, not we.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The city-mouth, that pecked us at my lodging last night, came to me with an abominable scratched face, and warned me on a business hither.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I smell some trick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Some treachery upon the brotherhood, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Timorous thing! what in our own quarter?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: If you doubt any thing, 'tis best remove.
The fellow was sorely handled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would but see the carcase of authority prance in our quarter, and we not cut his legs off. Welcome Tony, what hast thou brought the word here to pass for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, you must make a wedding-night on't Nick, Mihil will go no less.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: My vow is passed, and before you, sir, I confirm it. This is my wife. Anon, you shall perform the holy ceremony,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis well, pray sir, retire yourself to the next room there a while, and stay you with him, lady.
But what do you with Gabriel? Is it not time to wake him yet?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis now upon the point, has slept two hours.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Father, you'll see a brave experiment upon a gentleman that has been a youth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And of the Philoblathici, as we are now.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And since was grown one of the reformed, and we are now in practice to retrieve, and bring him back to his first condition.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you followed all Mihil's directions?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hitherto we have. First, you saw he was laid defunct in sack, next in his sleep, we have accoutred him in martial habiliments , and now we mean to wake him with alarms shall affright the silly humour out of him, and render him his warlike faculty, or our art fails.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where be the wenches?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The sisters of the scabbard, there's the sport on't. They have their parts to play upon him too. But for his drink now when he wakes, you said you would have a bottle of the woman's what do you call't yonder? the Medea.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What? the charmed liquor that Medea brewed to make old father Aeson young again?
Must that renew his youthful spirit in him?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, sack will do better. When he wakes he will be very dry, than a quart-draught of good canary will so screw him up. 'tis time 'twere now in practice. So, softly, softly. We must but half wake him at first.
sp.stage: A bed put forth, Gabriel on it, Betty and Frank.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O some small drink.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here, drink it off, sir,(Drinks)down and trumpet. An alarm.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surprised by th' enemy, whilst we have played the sluggard in our tents.

sp.speaker: Captain nick. Clot.
sp.p: Hold captain, hold, we are your soldiers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You're mutineers, and have disturbed my rest. And I'll do martial justice on you all.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, hold, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Know you not discipline? or are you grown rebellious in the camp. I'll teach you warfare.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You have conjured a fury into him to beat us into fitters.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: My pate bleeds for't; I protest.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'll make you know command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble commander, hold thy furious hand, and hear thy soldiers speak.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What have we women for our martial music?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: None but the she-trumpet, a neighbour here, and her sister, that was drum-major to my Country-amazons, that pulled up the enclosures to lie all in common.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is the enemy i'th' field?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Upon their march, captain, and we your officers: but roused you up to be in readiness.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
You are my lieutenant, you my ancient, and you two my sergeants; and you must know the commander
you serve under, to be none of those letter-carriers that know not so much as the terms of discipline, what a flanker is, nor a ravelin is. Nor a Petard is. Nor a curtain is. Nor a bulwark is. Nor a bastille is. Nor a counterscarp is. Nor a casemate is. A gabion is: nor any left word of fortification. How can such freshwater captain's command?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Right noble colonel. He shall be our colonel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: One soldier made up of sack, is worth as many as would drink a fresh water river dry.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I knew, men of abilities should at last be put in action.
sp.l: Valiant men and wise,
Are only fit for weighty enterprise.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O noble colonel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What would an upstart Militaster now, that knew no rudiments of discipline, nor art of war, do in a sudden service? or say, when I know how to have my ordnance planted here, my cavalry mounted here, my battery-discoverer on such a point, my trenches cut thus, my mine carried thus, my gabions raised thus. Here my parapet, there my palisado o'th' top of that. The enemy made unsaltable six hundred paces there. And I draw out my musketeers to flank 'em in their trenches here, while my pikes and targeteers advance to the breach there. What would captain, my lords man, or sergeant-major, my lady's kinsman, sent in by honourable favour, do or say in such an expedition?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Braver and braver still.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: This goes beyond the blade and the battoon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
Or how would their brains lie in their breeches, when the able captain leads up his men in the head of a troop bravely, charges with his shot,
makes a stand with his pikes, does execution with his sword, the cannon playing, the drum beating, the shot thumping, the ensigns waving, the arms clashing, the air rending, dust and smoke clouding, blood raining. And then to bring up such a division to fight, make good such a ground, relieve such a squadron, fetch off such a loss, reinforce the ranks that are broken. March on, come off. Beat the Besogne's that lie hid in the carriages. O the renowned life of a worthy commander.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sound drum and trumpet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A colonel, a colonel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Whither hast thou brought me? does thy brother lie speechless in this house? ha! what in the name of tumult can these be?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray sit, attend, you will be pleased anon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: A still march now. So, I have lost a great many of my men. But courage yet, you poor remainder of my scattered troops. Stand. Qni vala. An ambuscado of the enemy. Alarm. Lieutenant, charge in with your shot. Now gentlemen, for the honour of Covent-garden, make a stand with your pikes; in to the short sword; well fought, take prisoners. Sound a retreat now. Fair, fair i'th' coming off. So, 'twas bravely performed.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Must we not fall to rifling now, colonel.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Part fair on all sides, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What's this, a vision, sure I do ail something.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Is't possible it is thou? art thou run mad as far as hell the tother way now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.l: My wicked, caitiff, reprobate son is here too.
Pray let me flee, I am but a dead man else.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You shall receive no harm, sir lay by your arms my masters. I bring none but friends.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou canst not make that good, my father's there.

sp.speaker: Mih
sp.p: I'll make him friends with thee. Go and dispatch within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll see it done, and take our new made brides with us for witnesses.

sp.speaker: Rook
sp.p: Has his shame yet taught him to shun my sight.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And shall return him instantly your comfort.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Unpossible, unpossible.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Attend the event.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I rather thought I should have found you, sir, disputing with the pastors, and the elders; yet to say truth, this is the better madness. What can this mean? how came he thus translated? what charms, or what enchantments are upon him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What Babel was a building in my brains?
But now it turns, and I can recollect
The knowledge of a father, brother, sister.
And that a thousand vain imaginations,
Like scatterings of light things upon the earth,
Rushes, loose leaves, sprigs, straws, and dust
Contracted by a whirlwind, were blown up,
And lodged in the rich seat of contemplation,
Usurping there the room of virtuous thoughts.
Honour awake me from this lethargy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What can those women that appear like furies be in this action?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They were but used as properties to give new motion to his mortified condition.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
I know not what to say to any thing; there
is some spell upon me too. My anger has forsook me. What are those men that bear a countenance. As if they stood indifferently affected to bedlam and Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Meaning by us, sir. If our sight offend you,
Know we are men that dare forbear the place.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I son, let's go, our stay is dangerous.
They look like peace-maintainers, we'll fall off.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: O tarry, gentlemen, we are all undone else. If you make not your peace before you stir, both you and I must suffer.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: The magistrates and officers with their billmen have taken us by surprise. They are i'th' house.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O me! the blue gown college.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wheels and whips. I feel what we must go to. Did not I say our stay was dangerous?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Did not I say there was some subtle practice upon the Philoblatici? and that we were betrayed hither?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.p: There's no escaping forth. And gentlemen, it will but breed more scandal on my house, and the whole plantation here, if now you make rebellious uproar. Yield your weapons, and welcome justice but like subjects new, and peace will follow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: But where's Nick? where's Tony?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They shall yield up their weapons. So do you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes yes, 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Shall we, sir, shall we?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
So, sir, I will then, not the blade alone. But
for your more security, the battoon, there see my arms forth coming.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say they shall have fair welcome, what are they married?
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Dorcas, Ant. Kat. Luc.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, as fast as troth and holy words can bind 'em.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: 'Tis well. Now sir, let me entreat your favour.
'Tis my first suit to you since I was your son,
That before others entrances distract our troubled
Scene, these may be reconciled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Even unto the earth, sir, and humbled with as true a penitence, as son can be for wronging of a father, I beg your pardon and blessing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Give it him, brother Rooksbill, I dare say 'twill make him a good man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven make him so. My blessing and my prayers shall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What? my niece Dorcas made an honest woman?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Was that the man that wronged my cousin Dorcas?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and has now made ample recompense.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Here they are altogether, sir.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
Lay hands on all. First, on that old ruffian, the incendiary, that sets the youthful bloods on fire here with his infernal discipline. Next, take his sons, there's one, that young blade there, have I now got within ye, gentlemen? will you have songs ex tempore? know ye me now? A ha! I'll be caned the
weeder of this garden. Take up those she weeds there. I have the rank one here. I took her straggling in my round e'en now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My tenant, I take it, Mrs. Margery owlet.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your widow sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: But for a shift sir, now you know my aim.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O good your worship, as you came of a woman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Peace Circe's, cease thy charms. What cluster have we here now. O here's another of the sons of noise.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That's my son now, sir, by your leave, and I'll bail him.

sp.speaker: Cook
sp.p: What Mr. Rooksbil, are you here? what woman's this?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: My niece, sir, his son's wife. And I'll bail her.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What Mr. Croswill, you among this ging too?
How will you escape commitment?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Why, Mr. cockbrayne? how his brains crow now?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Who's here? your daughters too? but what are these?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I hope they'll prove my sons, and be indifferent men in time, sir, by that time their hair may grow, or be reduced to an indifferent length.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: That's done on me already, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now he looks as like a rogue as e'er he did again.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And sir, for me, now that my cousin is restored, and the wild fury of my wine abated.
I do you the obedience of a son, acknowledging my former formal habit was more of stubbornness then true devotion. For which I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: There's more deceit under these half footballs, then in whole pudding-bags. Well boys, be you indifferent sons, neither too hot nor too cold. I have found a fault in myself, I confess. I will reform it, and be an indifferent father.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O here's the man I sought, whom, I confess, I am half sorry to commit with the rest, because I found him civiller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hoping you will not stake that good opinion, I'll now come nearer to you. And since here is such a convention of love and joy. I hope my offering of a son's true duty may find I .

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What? my son Antony?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: How? how? your son that should have had my daughter? Come hither Kate, now if thou lovest him, take him. Are you content, friend cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O sir, most happily.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why run you not together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is too late, or needless now for me to marry her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is't come to that? and if I do not swinge him ‚Äî. Are you too good, sir, for my daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not say so, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Housewife, do you like him?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No more than he does me, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Get you together, or I'll swaddle you both into one, you perverse fools.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, we are married already.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: 'Tis so, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Heyday! who am I trow? how durst you do it without my consent?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I had your consent, sir, you commanded me to take my choice in whom I pleased, before you would take notice.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I cannot abide this wrangling. Give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Joy and my blessing on you. Why I know not whom to commit now.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You have done the commonwealth a special piece of service the while with your state-brains. But let us make a night of this, I pray.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.p: Sir, the parties have given me satisfaction, and I am content they be released.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: There's an honest fellow now, and looks like one that would be beaten every day for ready money. Go now, while ye are well, and be seen no more in this precinct.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Never and't please your worships, never.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: 'Twas built for no such vermin. Hence away.
And may the place be purged so every day.
'Tis no unworthy member may be found,
To pester or to vilify this ground.
That as it was intended, it may be
A scene for virtue and nobility.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: 'Tis not the poet's art, nor all that we
By life of action can present on't, ye
Can or ought make us to presume a play
Is good, 'tis you approve't. Which that you may
It cannot misbecome us, since our gains
Come by your favour, more than all our pains.
Thus to submit us unto your commands.
And humbly ask the favour at your hands.

div.head: Another.
div.l: 'Tis done. And now that poets can divine,
Observe with what nobility doth shine
Fair Covent-garden. And as that improves,
May we find like improvement in your loves.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
